div.head: TO CHRISTOPHER RICH Esq One of the Pattentees of His Majesty's Theatres.
div.p: THIS Play, the Conception of a few loose hours, being committed by the Author to my Hand to Dispose in the World, I cannot Discharge the Adoption I have taken of it better, than by making a Present of it here. And truly, SIR, for a Worthy Patron, You stand my Noblest Choice. Ev'n the proudest Greatness and Nobility are but Poorer Shrines to Offer at: For that Great Lord, and this Noble Lady, may Patronize a Play, and Cherish an Author: But You, SIR, in Your Higher Province, are the Support of Playing it Self. And if the Diversion of the Stage makes so considerable a part of the Entertainment of the Age; without Flattery, I may tell You, That Your Self is one of the Greatest Founders of that Feast. For no Man has pusht Fairer, or ventured Franklier, to carry on the Muses Cause, even in their Mourning Days, and most Declining Circumstances; and with that Unmurmuring Cheerfulness, that You never Repined at Your Profusest Favours in their Protection.

As You stand thus Extraordinary Qualified for this Humble Address; so I avow to the World, That I intend, in this Offering, a Piece of Devotion above that of a Common Dedication. For I do not so much Dedicate the Play to You, as I do my Self. You are so much the Gentleman (a Name that includes all Titles) in Your Candour and Goodness, and the Conduct of Your whole Administration amongst us, that nothing but the highest ingratitude can play the Infidel with You.

'Tis true, You have Unhappily met with too many Barbarous Returns from Murmurers and Mutineers, whilst the Popular Outcry of Oppression, the too Common, though never so False, Pretence for Rebellion, has not been wanting, to too many Renegadoes to fall from You: But as the fairest Standard and the Best Cause will sometimes have Deserters; their Revolt is their Shame, not Yours. For Your True Worth, when throughly known, will be found to stand above the Reach of their false Calumny and Detraction.
And against all such poor Apostacy, I here enter my publick Protestation and Abhorrence; and here, like an Honest Subscription to a Loyal Association, declare my self,

closer.signed: Your Ever Unshaken, and most truly Faithful Servant, GEORGE POWELL

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p: I Am not ignorant, that Criticks (like London Iuries) are ap●… i●… give quite different Verdicts upon the same Faults aggravated 〈◊〉 the same Circumstances; and the same Thing shall be Condemned as an Inexcuseable Fault in one, and Applauded as a Beauty in another. This Reflection made me at first unwilling to expose this Play to the publick View; but when I considered how many Young Criminals have found Favour, for no other Reason, (that I could find) but that it was their first Fault, I resolved to let it stand its Tryal, where I shall leave it to take its Fate according to its Deserts.

This Play was written for my own private Diversion in the Country where the Scene is laid, and brought on the Stage for the Diversion of others: If it has had the good Fortune to please, I have my end; If not, yet I hope my good Natur'd Intention will be so far from being Imputed to me as a Fault, that it will Atone (at least) for someof the Errors I have committed.

There is one Objection, made by Persons of that strange Antipathy to any thing that is Obscene, that the least tincture of it strangely Disorders them, that is laid to its Charge,
which, after the Plays I have seen crowded and admired, did not a little surprize me; for I was so far from being Conscious to my self, of having intrenched on Decency more than ordinary, that my greatest fear was, that it would prove too Modest for this Age: But I hope this is only a piece of Female Hypocrisie, and that which is condemned in publick will become Matter of private Diversion. But, Reader, I will stay thee no longer at the Door, go in, and see what the Nice Humour of this Age takes Offence at, and with me Congratulate the happy Change.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.stage: By Mr. Haines, in a Barrister's Gown.

lg.l: May it please this Honourable House,
MY Cornish Clyent, whose Muse is to be try'd,
Begs, what I humbly conceive, can't be deny'd,
That you'll admit me Counsel of his side.
We Claim it by the Act; Pray hear our Reason,
Nonsence is always in this Court held Treason.
Therefore,
I Move, That Silence in this Court be kept,
Whilst we against the Iury do except.
First then,
We Challenge Criticks; They don't Act like Christians,
They'r Hittites, Gergashites, they'r meer Physitians
To us I'm sure, and still will so remain,
Till Sampson like our Locks are grown again:
And next, All those who make a Trade of Writing,
As Fencing-Masters are forbidden Fighting.
We Challenge,
All Quality-Fops, that Whisper Orange-Wenches:
Why are such Locusts suffer'd on our Benches?
They put off rotten Oranges to a Novice;
Hussy's,
If you'd Thrive, Set up an Insurance Office,
In Cupid's Mansions, Lovers will desire,
That all his Tenants be secur'd from Fire.
We Challenge with Submission,
All your News Whisperers, who with wise Grimaces,
Carry the Fate of Kingdoms in their Faces;
In Theory of Warfare so well known,
That ere the Siege was laid, they'd ta'en the Town:
Be all such Coffee Iudges banisht hence,
Let 'um to Garraway's, there beat the French.
We Challenge Peremptorily,
All Toping Rakes that Booz till break a day,
Then Stagger to the Chocolate House, thence to the Play,
To Break a poor Fellow's Head would have 'um pay;
Thirsting for Fame, but Thirsting more for Drink,
How can they Iudge that can't pretend to Think:
My Client likes none of those for Iurymen,
No Soldier, nor no Courtier. With Submission, Who then?
Since he scorns Wits, and all Poetick Rules,
We move for a Jury of such the Wits call Fools.
Rich Country-Puts, and Grave Substantial Cits,
Who live on their own Estates, and not like Wits;
Well-meaning Dunces by Predestination,
That Laugh at all your frothy Wit o'th' Nation.
Who when you Wits Swear Damme! 'Tis all Stuff;
Will cry, No Faith, methinks 'tis well enough.
These are the Men that we expect to Night,
Should do both Vizor Mask and Poet right;
Like Hudibras, profound in Analiticks,
Such 〈◊〉 would save the Play, and Damn the Critick;
W●… 〈◊〉 such a Iury, our Poet will look as blank,
As he were to receive his Third day from the Bank.

div.head: The First Part of the Dialogue.
div.stage: Sung by Mr. Bowen and Mrs. Cross, between the Second and Third Acts. The Words by Mr. Haynes, and Set by Mr. Clarke.

sp.speaker: Damon.
sp.l: Let Cloris Smile on any Swain,
For I have got my Heart again,
Now your Smiles no Magick have,
But am no more her Slave.

sp.speaker: Cloris.
sp.l: Whilst Damon was to Cloris true,
E're my false one Thirsis knew;
Were we not then a happy Pair?

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: We were then a happy Pair.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Sure on earth was never known;
Each moment I dy'd with the thought of the Bliss,
And you breath'd a new Soul with each life-giving Kiss.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: When panting and fainting to Cloris I kneel'd,
How dear were her smiles, and how sweetly they kill'd?
But even then deceiv'd me too.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: As you us'd me, so I use you.

div.head: The Second Part of the Dialogue between the Third and Fourth Acts.
div.stage: Enter Damon and Cloris meeting one the other.

sp.speaker: Damon.
sp.p: WELL, Cloris, How find you your self sin●… you're free?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Since then from the cares of Love we are free;

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: And the doubts and the torments of curs'd Iealousy.

sp.speaker: Chorus.

p.hi: Sure nothing can be, no nothing can be, no, no, no, nothing can be

sp.l: So pleasant, so pleasant, as our Liberty.

sp.speaker: Damon.
sp.l: But hold! e're we part, What think you of this,
The Love's we began, mayn't we end with one Kiss?

sp.speaker: Cloris.
sp.l: Why, Cloris says— Cloris says— Yes.

sp.speaker: Da. (Kneeling).
sp.l: ‛ Can I no way deserve to have one Salute more?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: ‛ No, Damon, no more, I cannot, I may not,
‛ I dare not, bestow any more.
(Aside.) ' For should I give one, I should never give o're.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: ‛ Oh, let me one Kiss, one soft Kiss more steal.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: ‛ No, not while you to my proud Rival kneel.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: ‛ But say, if I my wandring heart,
‛ For Love of you call home again,
‛ Could you from your new Choice depart,
‛ And turn to your repenting Swain.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: ‛ Were Cerydon brighter than the day,
‛ Damon, the Coursest of the Swains, but True,
‛ I'd quit him and all the World, for you,
‛ I would Live with my Damon in a Desart alone,
‛ And envy no Monarch the empty delights of his

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: The more than Heavenly Ioys we taste below.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Will you do it e're we part?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Ay, indeed, now indeed, I'll do't e're we part.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: We'll do't e're we part, we'll do't e're we part.

div.head: Dramatis Personae.

row.cell: A Merchant, Old, Testy, Lascivious and Miserable.
His Son, in Love with Eugenia.
A good natur'd old Gentleman Plotting for the good of his Nephew, to whom he was a Guardian and a tender Uncle.
A true Country Squire that makes Recreations his business.
A broken Shopkeeper, his Follower, Treacherous and Hypocritical.
An ignorant Rhodomontade Captain of the Militia.
A Gentleman of a loose Temper.

div.p: A Parson, Four Bailiffs, Fowler, and other Attendants.

row.cell: The Daughter of Gripe, a Vertuous Lady.
Froth's Wife, Cunning, Imperious, and Impudent.

div.p: SCENE, CORNWAL.

div.head: THE Cornish Comedy.
ACT I. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: MArried, Sir, and to morrow say you?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: And pray, Why not to morrow, as well as to morrow twelvemonth? What have young Maids to do but to obey their Father's commands? I will defer the matter no longer.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Will you force Consent, Sir, and Inclination?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Consent, Sir, Cannot her Father tell what is fittest for her to consent to?— But Sons think it their greatest glory if they can contradict or teach their Fathers. The one is no wit unless the other be upbraided, and called Fool or Knave, at least by inference.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Sir, I have done.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: As I expected, the Father no sooner speaks, but the Son thinks his breath too good to be spent in such company.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Would you permit me, Sir, I would declare my mind at large.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Under Articles,— since it must be so, proceed with your Predicables and Predicaments, and other Items in abundance.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: By Natures dictate, each may chuse his Mate,
Man, Beast, and Bird,— and all that Generate;
Each Male his Female, liberty is Bliss,
And full content's a perfect Paradice.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Rhimes, never stir!— Rhimes! out of the School of Vertue, or some such precious Author; let the young Girls loose to temptation, they'l soon conceive the dictates of Nature. I tell you, Friend, I will maintain no Bastards.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: My Sister, Sir, I trust is Chaste and Vertuous.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: So are all young Women until they are tempted— a Woman's Chastity is not from her vertuous will or inclination, but because she hath not the power or opportunity to be otherwise; give her her wing, fancy will work a pace, and the first Gay Modish Spark, with long Beau Peruke and gawdy Snuff-box, may manage her at pleasure.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: By Nature all things covet liberty, but you compare your Childrento the Beasts, and because some of each Sex are brutal, condemn the whole, as if there were none but a compelled Chastity: You make the Jewel Vertue, a privation; who e're she grant a Wedlock, first causes a liking, then the noble passion Love, which once ingrafted in the Soul, the Marriage proves for ever comfortable.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: If it be once ingrafted in the Soul, 'twill not be long e're it get into the Body; Under what circumstances is your Vertue then Boy? Let the most transported Lover have but one quarter of an hour with the charming Fair, the Passion is over, and the crackt Venice-Glass returns to its first owner; once more, I tell you, I will maintain no Bastards.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Remark abroad, what you may dread at home; tell me of one forced Marriage that was not exemplarily miserable: The Persons are the Figures; the Portion, Jointure, and the Settlement, are Cyphers; if the first be good, the latter amplify, or of themselves are nothing. Oh! do not rashly tye the knot which you'l too late repent! When Bodies join without Affection, despair commences, and she will hate the Riches for the Owners sake; besides, you know her Promise made to Manley.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Promises,— never stir! hast thou lived to this age, and yet ignorant that Promises are no longer obliging than they serve the interest of him that made them? Were it an Oath, the dispensing power is in me, and she should break her Oath for Conscience sake.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: My Father takes Oaths like Apothecaries Pills, the less regarded, the better they settle in a squeazy stomach. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: For my dear Mothers sake grant me some respite. [Kneels and weeps.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Would'st thou delay thy happiness?— thou must and shalt obey.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: How now Miser? Still shewing new unkindness to thy Children?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Now my daily Ague comes to shake me.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: No thy ill Conscience flying in thy face, that never will let thee rest, thy rusty Soul hath infected thy Body with the Jaundice; thou sordid slave to Mammon without Wages!

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Would'st thou I spend by thy example, and be poor.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I'm much more rich than thou with all thy Gold, I have supplies which I and mine do use with full content and satisfaction; I give, I lend, I buy, pay every man his due without regret; I and my Family freely and proportionably share the blessings given us, live peaceably and hospitably, give liberablly to the poor; for which thou callest me Prodigal.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Better thou madest provision for thy Family, not frolick all away.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Thinkest thou I'll live my days in misery like thee, to die rich, unthank'd, and unlamented: I would not for thy wealth share thy disquiets, 'tis he is poor, so anxious is, and careful, that hath not Soul to enjoy what himself possesseth. Clarinda weeps still, Miser! What is the meaning?

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: For joy to morrow that she shall be Married.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: For Joy, wretched Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: To the discreet and most accomplish'd Squire Swash.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: The same, Sir, I have lived so long in the world to know that a rich Fool is to be preferred before a wise Beggar; the Wit may give you starving mirth, but the rich man fills the Belly; mind that Mrs. Minx, better doctrine than your Brother preaches.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I met this famous Squire even now at yonder Alehouse-door drinking Brandy, and such an Equipage I feared at first, from whence they came a broken Shopkeeper, his sycophant and flatterer, the hired Ingineer of his Masters more speedy destruction; a Huntsman with some twenty couple of Hounds; Six men with Cocks in bags; one with a Hawk on his fist, leading a pair of Spaniel Dogs in strings; a Fisher with Fishing-tackle; Fowler with Fowling-piece; the Squire winds the Horn, the Men Halloo, the Dogs Eccho such a prodigious noise as they call Harmony.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: He brings his whole Family with him to save charges at home. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What an extravagant Character is here!

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Sports incident to Youth,— he shall be Married, Madam, and then no danger of his taking up,— he comes. [Horn winds.

div.stage: Enter Swash, in one hand an horn, in t'other a Pole; Sharper with an Hare and Pole in the other hand; Six men with Cocks in Bags; Fisher with fishing rods; Fowler with Fowiling Piece; Fawknor with Hawk on his fist, leading a pair of Spaniel Dogs in strings, all the Men with Poles in their hands, and all other things proper to their respective Games.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Leave the Dogs without,— Venus is proud, tye her up till to morrow, Iupiter and Tarquin must be secured, or they'l rove after the Conies; Little Cupid too must be narrowly eyed, he'l be shifting in every corner, if the Kitchin-wench spill any of her hot Liquor upon him he may be spoiled for ever,— Sharper let it be your care to morrow when I am in Bed with my Mistriss, that all living Creatures that belong to me be let loose together.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Squire, you are welcome, you continue your innocent diversions.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, What's a Gentleman without his Recreations? With these we endeavour to pass away that time which otherwise would lie upon our hands, Hawks, Hounds, Setting Dogs, and Cocks with their appurtenances, are the true marks of a well-bred Country Gentleman; and because 'tis ridiculous to be without some, I have 'um all, and put 'um up with me where-ever I go.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: You do well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: I must desire good quarters for my Hounds, they have run hard to day.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: You shall, I promise you.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Sir, you forget your Lady.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: My Plough wrought hard, 'tis prudence to see my Beasts provided for before I regard my self.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: He cares more for his Hounds than thee, Clarinda. Aside to each other.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Wou'd he would take no farther care of me.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Your Huntsmen hath taken care of them.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: If so, then for the other Game. Is this to be my Spouse?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I know not what my Fates decree— phoh! how he stinks of Brandy and Tobacco! [Aside and Spits.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: The Fates, Madam, are a parcel of old withered Witches, for us they shall spin Cables; thou shalt be my Diana, I thy Pan; thou shalt dance to my Pipe.— Sharper, the Hare, Madam, I present the fruits of this days labour to you. [Gives the Hare.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Genteel and Frugal,— some Prodigals would have bestowed a hundred Guineas in a Jewel. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: With my own hands I took her up before the Hounds, a while she beat her foyl, and once we were at a shrewd fault; I back'd it, I put forth, I rounded, I fresh found her, Halloo! (quoth I) thou art mine own Bird now, and thus I fairly killed my Hare.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, What are these?

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: True Cocks of the Game,— Let me see the old Cutthroat.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Sir, you neglect your Lady. [takes out a Cock.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: I have kiss'd her, and now I'll shew her my best Cock,— What can I do more before all this Company? Pray handle him, Madam, Is he not a sprightly Cock?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: It may be so, I have no judgment.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: In good time, Madam.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: 'tis a Chargeable Recreation.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: That's your mistake, Sir, I make all my Recreations turn to advantage, I hunt my Hounds for a Treat, no matter whether I win or loose, it answers the end of drawing of Company; as soon as we are warm with Liquor, I make a match of Cockfighting, and then a Hundred or Two hundred Pounds are soon won, for I never fight a Battel under; this Cock first and last hath won me a Thousand pound, pierc'd often through the Brain, thrice his Neck was broke, and once his Head quite cut off, and yet he got the Battel.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: You are not always certain of success.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: A secret I give my Cock when I throw him into the Pit, he does his work, while you say what's this; or if we come to put to, I never fear, for we carry a close heel.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Never stir, I admire when pleasures turn to accompt, 'tis very commendable; and for your better instruction in the affairs of the world, mind this infallible receipt, do no good, take no wrong, keep what you have, catch what you can, and pay no body.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: But where is my Reputation.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: A gloss, a varnish, a blind to amuse the unthinking world, a trap for Woodcocks, necessary sometimes to a declining state, or one turning Bankrupt, credit for a short time perhaps diverts that storm otherwise inevitably happening, and helps at last to buoy him on anothers ruin.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: As some Marry to stop a gap, (as we say).

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: True— but if men gallop up the hill; Fame is the rich man's shadow, and follows at your heels whether you will or no.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Indeed.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: For instance, people discoursing of me, That miserable old Dog is worth thousands (say they).

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: So scurrilous!

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: I know it, and am proud of it, for under that creditable Character, my word will pass for more Money than the most accomplish'd Coxcomb, or man of Sense, that comes from Court or City, or from either of the Universities or Inns of Court,— but I judge you may be weary, and and Supper is almost ready, I'll lead the way.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir,— Madam your hand; along Boys, Sesse, Sesse. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Where is the Courtship all this while, Peregrine?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Within after Supper, his Love always moults on an empty Stomach. [Exit.

div.stage: [As Sharper is going, Trusty takes him by the Sleeve, Sharper starts.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: At whose Suit, pray?— He is no Creditor, I never saw his face before,— nor Bailiff by his Cloaths, though he hath a suspicious face. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Mr. Sharper (for so I am told you are called) I am desirous of an intimate acquaintance with you; I admire Vertue and Honesty in every man.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Is the Man Drunk or Mad, I never had a dram of either, they lie not in our way. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Pity it is such worth should lie buried in obscurity, we should improve our Talents to the utmost to relieve our needy Brethren in distress.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: A Religious preface,— commonly mischief intended in the Treatise. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: My Bowels yearn to see such men in want,— pray, Sir, accept this Token of my Friendship. [Gives a Purse.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Ha! Gold, and Twenty pieces!— How may I deserve this! but 'tis meer folly for men in adversity to dispute these matters,— what e're be the event, I take the press money,— if Shipwreck'd I have but this Hull to lose, and that is not very stanch,— Fortune can never make me much less than nothing. [Aside]. Sir, I thank you,— I suppose these golden rays have their attendance; What work must I do to merit all this?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: The earnest of Two hundred more forth coming, if thou wilt be my Friend.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Two hundred more!— 'tis enough to retrieve my Shop and Credit, I find I was mistaken in the Gentleman, on second thoughts, methinks he hath a very honest promising Countenance. [Aside]. Your Commands, Sir, I thirst to be in action.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Wilt thou be secret?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: As your own thoughts,— by this sacred purse I swear, we that take Bribes, take examples by our Betters, be true to our Customers for the sake of Trade, whatever it be, I'll do it as readily as ever Prisoner Perjured himself on the Ten pound Act; as greedily, and with as much zeal as ever Clergyman Ruined his Parishioner for a Tythe Pig or Goose.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Wilt thou Betray thy Master to me?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Is this Body mine? My whole shall be your security; come come, the method, lets about it.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Of that anon,— in, in, you'l lose your Supper.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: This dear restorative will cure all hunger,— Oh, Gold! dear precious Gold! thou Liberty and Property, Religion and the Laws; thou every thing to a despairing Tradesman, welcome: Now by this precious Villany, and its wages, I'll suddenly compound with my Creditors, go snips with 'em, and set up for Honest Tom. Sharper the Shopkeeper again, this may make me Mayor of a Corporation in a short time, and then I'll pay off the arrearages of my Debts (if any) out of the publick stock.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: He is overjoyed. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: If want of Money be the Quagmire of the Court, it is certainly the Jakes of the Country, which makes the poor Creatures so nauseous that they are spued out of all Company; when I broke— my Neighbours could not endure me, and no name was bad enough; when I set up again, they'l flock about me with all the kind pretensions imaginable. Thy Golden days are coming, Tom,— blest reformation! [Aside.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Mr. Sharper you forget your Supper.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I had almost forgot my self,— shall I attend you here, or where, Sir?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: In the Garden, our discourse may be over-herad here.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Prudent forecast,— no wonder Men say, Wealth is the wisdom of a Nation, Gold plentifully got works by sympathy over all the body, and all the words are Oracles. In the Garden an hour hence, I will wait your commands, and if I do not prove as honest a Traytor as ever took cause in hand, let me be hanged, drawn, and quartered. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: How suddenly the needy wretch was caught! He swallowed the bait as soon as offered: Now by the strength of mighty expectation the ungrateful Creature sells the hand that feeds him; my Nephew Manley, to whom in his Minority I was a Guardian, lies under as 〈◊〉 a Contract with the fair Clarinda as (without the solemnity of Marriage) can be obliging, she may be a great Fortune, he hath a fair Estate, though not so great as that Fops within, that crammed Son of a— miserable Usurer, a working Tinner; with like success Gripe's Son Courts Manley's Sister▪ on one thred all depends, the part seems difficult, but I must wade through by seeming and clandestine means.

div.p: Here poor Clarinda comes in Tears.— I'll try her Constancy— Clarinda, why disconsolate so near your Wedding day?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Name not that miserable Day, I much more willingly would court my Death; now help my Tutelar Angel; now, or never help! [Kneels, weeps.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Arise Clarinda, what wouldst have me do?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Beggars must kneel, pity my Misery.— Must I be ravished from my dear, dear Manley's Arms. You, Sir, that know the Secrets of our Hearts, the Vows, the sacred Promises we made each other before your Face, and with your Approbation, can you be ignorant what I would have you do?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I pity Manley's fate. You have a richer Husband brought you, Madam. Manley, poor Creature, grieves at his own unworthiness; which takes you from him, wishing you all happiness, insists not on the Pre-engagement; concludes you act meerly by compliance to your Father.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Nay, then he loves me not; true Affection cannot be limitted by Interest or blind Obedience— False Manley! treacherous Manley! No, it cannot be, Manley— continues just, but thinks me false; thinks all my kindness was a bare Pretence or Civility.— A time will come to prove my Constancy.— I'll to my Father instantly,— tell him I'll never marry Swash. Manley! for me thou languishest with patience; and shall Clarinda basely and unworthily neglect her plighted Promise to thee?— No, Manley, it never shall be said, Clarinda's false. [Exitura.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Clarinda stay,— one remedy is left; by your assistance I can break the Cloud hangs o're our heads. [Return.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Speak on, dear Oracle! I will do any thing to serve my Love.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Give this your Father before he Sleeps. [Shews Paper of Powder.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ha! will you poyson him? and by mine Hand?— Give it me, if it need blood to bring it to perfection.— I offer a Virgin Sacrifice, but ne're consent to my dear Father's Murther.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Clarinda, this was but a trial,— that Fop shall never wed thee. Fear not, I'll stand 'twixt thee and harm, my dear Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Will you kill my Father, Sir?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: No, I abhor such hellish Crimes.— I have the Plot so firmly here projected; within few days thou shalt be Manley's Bride, and with thy Father Gripe's consent.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: This, tho improbable, I would believe. May you succeed, my Courage now revives.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: What remarks within?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: With fears and troubles I was so perplext, I scarce remember what was said or done.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: How got you from the Squire?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Supper brought in, he quitted his hole, falls to ere any Grace was said, quarters a Capon, throws it his Dogs; which he call'd Trey and Cater, crie●…,
A wise Man first feeds his Beasts, which he repeats for a witty Saying. Having my liberty, I hastened to find you, which happily I did, this is what I can say.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: And it is time, Clarinda, to adjourn, Sharper expects me in the Garden, be you as gay and easy as you can; prevent all cause of Jealousy; of what occurs give full intelligence with all conveniency.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I shall, with my utmost care and application.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: And for the rest,
sp.l: Leave it to me, I'll play the Pilots part,
And reach the Port, or perish in the Art. [Exeunt.

div.head: ACT II. SCENE I.

lg.head: A SONG sung to Manley musing in his Chair. Sung by Mr. Leveredge. Set by Mr. Clark.
I.
lg.l: WHEN Maids live to Thirty, yet never repented;
When all Europe's at Peace, and all England contented;
When no Gamester will swear, and no Bribery thrives,
Young Wives love old Husbands, young Husbands old Wives;
When Landlords love Taxes, and Soldiers love Peace,
And Lawyers forget a rich Client to fleece.
When an old Face shall please as well as a new;
Wives, Husbands, and Lovers, will ever be true.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: When Bullies leave buffing, and Cowards their trembling,
And Courtiers, and Women, and Priests their dissembling.
When these shall do nothing against what they teach,
Pluralities hate, and we mind what they preach;
When V●…tners leave brewing to draw the Wine pure,
And Quicks by their Medicines kill less than they cure.
When an old Face shall please as well as a new,
Wives, Husbands, and Lovers will ever be true.

div.p:
Manley riseth, Enough,— This is no cure for my Malady,— What a miserable Wretch is Man!— Condemned to Passions, captivated by 'em— We are the Monarchs o're all other Creatures, yet Anarchy predominates in us. The Sences in Confederacy raise Rebellion against reason; there now is a Civil War over all this Compound Tabernacle. Pride and Desire disturb the Harmony of Government, endeavouring to undermine the tottering Fabrick, and to hurl all into Chaos and Confusion.— Such is my
case, the Love of a Woman; mine she is by contract, and I am satisfied she bears me a reciprocal Affection. Shall I suffer her to be torn from me by that tawdry Bubble? I am in a Labyrinth— ha! Freeman come to teaze me!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ned Manley! and alone! throw off this self entertaining humour, let's take a Bottle, and wash away Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Prithee be gone, I'm serious.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Sir, I am glad you are come,— here is a rich pile of building shaken by a storm, and like to fall to ruin, wants a Supporter.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Clarinda has her cue, and by this time Sharper is at work,— now for my other Patient,— [Aside]— Nephew, How d'ye?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: As well as the Image of a man, a mere Statue, deprived of Sense and Reason, can be; like a Bird insnared, the more I strive for liberty, the more I am intangled.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: What means this passion? Are there no more Women?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Would there were none at all!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Nay, Manley, there I am utterly against you, though to have and to, hold till death us do part, &c. goes against the hair, yet for an hour or two they are very convenient things, and very good Company.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: You like not Maraiage, Mr. Freeman.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: 'Tis a Mortgage for Life, without Equity of Redemption.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Thy wild discourse too much offends me now.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Because thou hast not the Grace to hearken to good edifying doctrine,— Woman's expelled by Woman; take another, you may have a great penniworth, if these Wars hold, they'l speedily be the plentiest Commodity going, they lie every where upon their Father's hands; if any of 'em catch me in the noose of Matrimony, they shall assuredly pay for it; but I desy the Devils and all their works.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Yet Greece and Troy had Ten years War about a Woman.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: That was a handsome Whore, Sir,— it seems in that Golden Age of simplicity such a dish was reserved for Kings and Princes only, now the times are altered, the world is more Civilized, and a good natured and honest fellow need not starve for want of a bit to stay his stomach.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I can no longer listen to this Fop.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Nephew,— I should be glad if you could fix your thoughts upo●… some other Beauty.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Impossible— the more I'm in danger of losing Clarinda, the more I Love her.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: You know to morrow she must be another's, then of necessity your passion must divert.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Despair commences, but true and vertuous Love till death I shall have for her.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Can any man but pity him? [Aside.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How does Clarinda bear this sudden change?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Indeed but heavily, she laments sincerely.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: and I as heartily do pity her. Won't the great argument of Wealth convince her? Marriage is become a way of Purchase, or making Bargains; How many cautious Parents fondly persuade and force their Children to inconvenient and unwelcome Nuptials, that they may live miserably Rich,— Unfortunate Clarinda! I must pity thee.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: With Tears and Sighs she mournfully cried, Must I be Ravish'd from my dear, dear Manley's Arms! no, I'm his till death, and ne're will be another's.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Did I not tell you I forgave that Promise.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I told her so; she told me, you Loved her not, but thought her False, then nobly Vow'd she'd die to be believ'd.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Unkle, you blow the Coals afresh, I'm more a fire than ever.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: And can you Love Clarinda heartily?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Is that become a question? You know till death I must.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Love on.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Love on, Clarinda shall be thine, maugre what Gripe, and Swash, and all can do. [Whispers.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: The old Gentleman, I know, hath too great a kindness for him to abuse him, yet to me this discourse seems as if it would make him fit for Bedlam; 'tis all a mystery.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sir, You tell me impossibilities.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: It's a certain truth, I'll tell you more anon— Mr. Freeman you are Melancholy.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Manley bear up! between an Old Man and a Young Woman, I reckon thou art in the high road of Madness.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Captain Busy is without, desires admittance. [Exit Boy.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Wait on him in,— he pretends Love to my Sister; prithee Tom help me to abuse him.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Give him free liberty, he'll do it himself sufficiently,— now for a Lecture of Discipline; provide for his coming, you'll be both Exercised.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: He won't Beat us?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: No, no, only teach you the Postures, he carries a book in his Pocket out of which he is always practising.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Is he a good Soldier?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: A Militia Officer, but a great Blunderer; no more, he comes.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Noble Captain you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Your Servant Mr. Manley— though late, I was resolved to call in my way home.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No Complements amongst Friends, good Captain, you are welcome here at any hour.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: I was detained about a troublesome business, I have been sitting upon the great Rate.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: 'Tis well known you were ever zealous in publick matters, Commissioners ought to be so.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: A Hangman might hope for some end of his business; some Fools make the matter as intricate, as the Learned Doctors Scriblings are about Religion, no man can tell what they would be at.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: But you brought off all with good success.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Thank Patience and a good Head; one cries the Seas are block'd up and we have no Trade, therefore we must not be too severe to the Country; another, That Money is scarce, and other Counties don't come up to our proportion; I told them plainly, They that were not for giving this King Money, were for bringing in the other; at last I had my way, and the thing was Signed according to my mind.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But Captain, here's an old Friend of mine, if you are not provided, you had best take him for your Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Is he a Soldier?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The best in the Country.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: What dost mean? I'll discover my ignorance. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Peace put on an impudent face, thou wilt pass muster. Impudence is as requisite in a Soldier as in a Lawyer or a Physitian, if you have good stock, you are noted and admired, but want that, want all.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: If your Friend will accept of a Lieutenancy of the Militia, I have a blank Commission; but first I must exercise him.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Captain, I understand no more than a Maypole.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: No matter, I'll teach you; one Officer of understanding is enough for one Company,— but now I think on't, I have some Neighbours without that wait for me, I'll call 'em in, you shall see them Exercise.

div.stage: A Posture-Dance in imitation of Soldiers Exercise.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: This is excellent, a man may venture to fight with these Weapons without danger of death, or breaking of Bones.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: To tell you the truth, I don't think the Militia is oblig'd to fight; they are intended, I suppose, more for show than service; when the French Burnt Tinmouth, the Posse led the Van, the Militia the Rear.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Because the Militia is the standing Guard of the Nation.
Methinks, Captain, 'tis reasonable we should earn our Pay: I am for Fighting.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: The Fellow is the fitter for my service; though Valour in two Officers be too much for one Company, yet 'tis convenient there should be one such Officer; I for Conduct, he for Courage— I defie the whole Regiment to match us. He hopes for Pay; let him; I could never see any such thing, I believe it may be converted to other Uses. [Asi●…] But where is the fair Eugenia? I must kiss her hand before I sleep.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I had forgot to tell you Captain, that a brisk young Gentleman hath brought his Forces before the Town, and swears he'll take it by Storm or by Siege.

sp.speaker: Bus
sp.p: Dare any person be so Impudent— Dost thou not feel me yet! not yet! (Blusters) Though Hills were set on Hills, and Seas met Seas, yet would I reach thine head, thine head, proud— Ha! [Starts.]

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Now is your time, Captain; for if her flag of Truce be put up, there will be a speedy end of the Siege.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Madam, your humble Servant— Now for my great and manly looks to put him out of countenance. [Salutes, and looks big.] Hark ye, Sir,— Have you any Acquaintance with this Lady?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Darest thou, Thing! ask me such a Question? [Turns to him.

sp.speaker: Bus
sp.p: Thing— Dux, ducis, a Duco, a Thing! If I run him through before he turn his face, I'll venture to fight with him afterwards. [Draws and runs at Per. Eug. skre●…ks, Per. looks about, steps back and draws.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Look to your life, Peregrine.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Behind my back— Cowards are ever mischievous; now I am ready for you. [Makes up to him.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Will no body part us; [Locks back o●…r his Shoulder.] I am slain. [Lets his Sword fall, and falls on his Back.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: 'Tis with your fear then; I had not time to touch thee: However, I'll make bold with your Sword to prevent future mischief.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: You may rise, Captain, you have no hurt; let me help you. [Tr. helps.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: I'm sure I felt the Sword pass through the Triangle of my Heart— What, tho you see no Blood, 'tis a sign of the greatest danger when the Wound bleeds inwardly.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: You have no Wound.

sp.speaker: Bus
sp.p: That you saw: I felt it I'm sure, or I was sore mistaken— Where is this Lieutenant of mine, that could see his Captain slain before his face, and not revenge his Blood? I think he'll prove a special Officer.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Man to man— 'twould have been Cowardize to have interpos'd.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: I must be kill'd to make you sport— Here's a Dog deserves to be hang'd for not following the example of his Superiour Officer— It is for thee, dear Saint, the Love of thee, I suffer all these evils. [To Eugenia.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: For me— I am not worthy of such respect from a Person of your Quality.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Pretty Creature, thou hast some Compassion. [Takes her by the hand.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Tho' I could pardon your cowardly aiming to take away my life, I cannot allow such familiarity with my Mistress.

div.stage: [Twinges him by the Nose, and turns him back.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Disarm'd and twing'd by the Nose— Nature was too niggardly to allow me none but Passive Valour— Poor Captain Busy Thou must bear thy Crosses with Patience— to the right hand about— [Acts as he speaks.] march, to the left— Halt! Now while he hath her by the hand, and may say and do what he pleases, I am allowed none but backward Kindness: I'll be tryed by any Man in England if this be not Arbitrary Power in the highest degree.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You have not raised the Siege, Captain.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: I endeavoured to beat the Enemy out of his Trenches, but the Lieutenant did not second me with his Body: I threw at all; wiser Commanders without. Disgrace have been worsted on such terms. [Aside to each other.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Rally again, Captain; Fortune favours the bold, you may have better success the second Charge; you scorn to desist on the first Repulse.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: I beg your Pardon, Sir,— [Sees 'em whispering.] A prudent General foresees Dangers, and will not Fight till he see an advantage or opportunity; I content my self with a fair Retreat— Though I die for't, I must hear what they say. [Listens.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: My Brother's Fate and mine shall be the same.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Then I have hopes, if he succeed I may be happy.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: You know my Resolution.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: 'Tis so; He hath laid a Train, and is going to spring his Mine; through the Breach he enters; no relief to be had, she must surrender at Discretion: She's lost she's gone, since of her self she will not love, nothing can make her; the Devil take her. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Listning? [Goes towards him, Busy runs out.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I must follow him about some private Business of my own.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Take his Sword with you, and bid him use it more discreetly for the future, left he meet a Wound in earnest— [Exit Fre.] Manley, I bring unwelcome News, by my Father's Commands I am to invite all here to my Sister's Wedding to morrow.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Now, Uncle, Where's your Stratagem?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And what is become of your full-blown hopes? [Smiling.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I rest securely in your Promises.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: They are Conditional.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Sharper hath private Business with Mr. Trusty— we must withdraw.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: It seems you know it. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: So shall you in time convenient— Now Sharper! How goes Matters on?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: With full Sails, Sir. When I left you, I went to Nich. Froth's, the Ale House yonder, where luckily I found my full Club of Catchpoles sitting at the Receipt of Custom, cursing some Attornies that Cheat them of their honest Wages.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Will they Espouse the matter?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Will they Eat when they are Hungry? I no sooner delivered my Message, but off slew their Caps, and your Worship's Health went round; They'll stand by you with their Lives and Fortunes; One of them's a broken Lawyer—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Do Lawyers break?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: When Vermine breed too fast, they will devour each other: The Priests monopolize the Parishes, therefore they seldom break; Phyfitians here and there pick up a Livelyhood, tho' small Apothecaries and Licensed Chirurgeons, and old Women discerning States, incroach on that Art and Profession: Shoopkeepers, like Foxes in their holes, walk forward and backward, but can prey no further than their Chain permits 'em; and as a broken Shooemaker makes a good Cobler, so a broken Attorney makes the best of Bayliffs.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: What said this Bayliff-Lawyer t' ye?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: First very strange, with open hand he stood, till with a Guinea I shook him by the Fist: My Darling, he cried, I'll do it effectually; Then taking an old Warrant out of his Pocket, enters his Name, what Sum, and at whose Suit: Next week, (said he) if he stand out, we'll send for the Writ; If he comply, we need not send for any; yet he must pay for that and the Declaration; This is the way small Fellows get their Bread, the great ones vast Estates: We could not live should we do all things Just; our Trade is a Mystery, and to keep Clients in profound Ignorance, our great Arcanum.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: They'll do their work to morrow?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Very early: Bayliffs and Woodcocks make their best speed by Twilight. Shall he be carried to a Tavern, Sir? or where?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: To that very Ale-House; He'll find those Charges high enough; Taverns are places unfit for Bayliffs. Dost think he'll fight his Cocks?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: He certainly shall do it, and I'll so order matters, you shall get every Battle.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Be the whole purchase yours.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Generously said, I expect no more; My little Bayliff-Lawyer hath forged this Letter to the old Gripe from his Tinn Captain. [Shews a Letter.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Thou hast betraved my Cause thou Villain.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Nay, See if it be not exactly to your Model. Reads,

Sir, Our Tinn-Work proves very poor, 'twill not pay Wages: if it does not alter within a week. I resolv●… 〈◊〉 kick it off and discharge some of the Men, unless I have
contrdry Orders from you by the Bearer. In Mr Manley' s Bounds adjoyning, there's a rich load cut 6 Foot broad without Water, and perfect Pryan, each Sack of Work makes his Gallon of Block Tynn: This I thought fit by Express to warn you of, that it might come before his from his Captain; The Bearer if examined will inform you farther; I rest in haste, Your Obedient Servant,
Stephen Spalding.
Now the same Lawyer shall be the Messenger in a Tinner's Disguise.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: If he be trusty, it seems feasible.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: I'll pawn my life for his Truth and Honesty.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: To confirm this, we must contrive another Note for Manley.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Leave it to me— But Business now grows thick, and waits dispatch, I must go my Rounds again before I sleep, and give fresh Orders. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sir, I cannot sleep before you tell me what are the intents of those so secret Meetings; I fear some ill design that doth relate to me.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Pray, Nephew, whence proceeds this Jealousie? I can swear, and that with safety, hitherto I have been faithful to my Trust.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sir!—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I han't as Trustees now too often do, plundered your Fortune to advance my own, and with bare fac'd and sinister contrivance in your Minority, with your Money purchased an Estate in my own Name, to my own Use and Benefit; Such Trustees (Nephew) are easily found, and such a poor Cullied Heir, when he arrives to the Age of 21, care being first taken he shall be no Scholar, Seals a General Release, which with ease is gotten, before Accompts or any thing like it are past, or perhaps called for; From which time the treacherous Panther regains the Prize, keeps his still Minor at due distance, takes upon himself the manage of his Profits, learns him the sweet and tantalizing way of squeezing Wax; at all times to be his security, and pay the whole Debt himself: In this poor Creature's Ashes the Salamander thrives and grows fat.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I own, Sir, your Actions and Accompts were ever clear and candid.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Now declare the Design, 'tis time to let him know it.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I will. Observe me then: A forged Letter sent supposed from Spalding, informs old Gripe of a rich Tinn-Work cut in your Bounds adjoyning, and confirmed by another Letter given you as from your Captain; you may guess the influence on his wretched Thoughts; mean while the Squire lies under an Arrest, and in that hurry you privately Espouse Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Forgery and Cheating, and I an instrument! The very shadow of one single Crime sufficeth to procure a publick blame; whereas a thousand Virtues are no more than necessary to acquire a general Approbation; all Men take notice of few Faults, but few enquire, or at least take notice, if a Life be led by the Concatenation of all Moral Virtues,

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Good Moral Actions have naturally a right to Felicity, of which those often fail, who through their own default and infidelity make their first rights unuseful to themselves, which plainly shews all actions purely performed for Virtuous Ends, be they particular or general, level and go directly towards Goodness, altho' a man dream not of its tendency to that end.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But if these tend to Pleasure, Profit, or Ambition, they are inordinate Passions and unlawful Objects, and are not able to imprint in moral Acts other than blind Injustice or Dishonesty; We are told, that we ought to speak what is true, and do what is honest: Where's there room then for Dissimulation?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Mistake me not; I don't intend to Cheat him of his Gold.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But of his Child you do.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: As a Physitian cheats his Fevorish Patient of his Blood; I'll put a Blister on shall drein out all his Covetous Humour; I'll make a Knave an honest Man. That's as much as an Act of Parliament can do.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sir, you surprise, stagger me, on each hand I perceive a Precipice; on one side I'm undone.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: To undo ones self on one side, is no less than to be undone on both.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Can you persuade Clarinda?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: That's already done.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Proceed!— Try if you can our Fate retrieve;
What we desire, we easily believe.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

div.head: ACT III.
SCENE I. A Field.
div.stage: Enter Shuffle like a Tinner, with four Bayliffs.

sp.speaker: Shufflle.
sp.p: COme Boys, along, along, the day begins to appear; 'tis time to be boulting out of our lurking holes.

sp.speaker: 1 Bayl.
sp.p: A rea, rea, Master, What would you have done? Don't you think we know our own time? I have served two seven years to the Trade, and am not now to learn, that to do our business in the night is the way to be taken for House-breakers.

sp.speaker: 2 Bayl.
sp.p: For you know Master, if we disturb Men in bed with their Wives, they'll swear against us out of revenge.

sp.speaker: 3 Bayl.
sp.p: Every body hates men of our Profession; therefore, good sweet loving Sose, let us take special care what we do, for as sure's I am here they will do us a mischief if it lies in their way, for the publick good, as they call it, tho' they get nothing by it themselves.

sp.speaker: 4 Bayl.
sp.p: Shure and Shure, and so they wull; 'tis a dangerous world, people don't care what they swear.

sp.speaker: 1 Bayl.
sp.p: The Justices of the Peace don't care to meddle with you Lawyers; you all joyn to help a distressed Brother out of the Mire.

sp.speaker: 2 Bayl.
sp.p: For every one reckons it possible to be his Lot next.

sp.speaker: 3 Bayl.
sp.p: But Justices and other Gentlemen are weary of prosecuting them, because they have little redress or encouragement when it comes to the Test.

sp.speaker: 4 Bayl.
sp.p: Shure enough; They'll be shure to be cheated, and all the blame lie on our backs; therefore good sweet loving Sose, let's take special care what we do.

sp.speaker: Shuffle.
sp.p: Impudent Rascals! Who taught you to prate thus? Whom do you get your Bread by? When you ignorantly run beyond your Warrants, Who brings you off with flying Colours? How many times have you been catched thieving, plundering, beating, wounding, and sometimes murthering poor harmless People? Yet, when the worst hath happened, we have joyned forces to make it out that what you did was in execution of your Office, justly in your own defence; and at last have Bribed the Petty Jury perhaps to acquit you.

sp.speaker: 1 Bayl.
sp.p: But who puts us upon it? Answer me that Question: We bear all the Backbitings, Curses, Distraces, Imprisonments, Indictments upon Indict●…. Bound over from 〈◊〉 to Sessions, from Assize to Assize, 〈◊〉, and ●…k here and there and every where; sometimes to Prison, 〈◊〉 to the common Gaol, stand Arraigned, and sometimes in danger of our lips; and because you put your helping hands to get us off, we 〈◊〉 holding to you; You run away with the Purchase and the Profit, leave us poor 〈◊〉 Creatures the blame, the pain, the hazard and the disgrace; you 〈◊〉 to be thanked and truckled to, as you had done wonders; very 〈◊〉 〈◊〉!

sp.speaker: So▪
sp.p: Peace, you sawcy Dog, or I'll discard thee instantly.

Do; and 〈◊〉 tell how many Writs thou hast made in an Ale●… or i●… 〈◊〉 own Chamber; and how many thou hast caused to be 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 any ●…rit: Four honest Men for Capias, Declarations, &c. which 〈◊〉 ●…es co●… thee not one peny, Twenty Shillings a Man. If it be not 〈◊〉 the first Term, Signing. Judgment entering upon the Roll, and other 〈◊〉, th●… nothing done, Five Pounds a Man; if a Bail, Bond, and Execution— Tho' the Coroner never Signed the Warrant, Twenty Pounds a Man, if—

sp.speaker: Shuffe.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Starter, no more if's, Prithee.

sp.speaker: 1 Bayl
sp.p: You know very well I can remember the particulars, and a great many others; you have brought such Fame upon the Law, that for the generality, as they had rather Die than use the second means from the Physitian; so they'll rather run the hazard of losing their Money, than ven●…re the Charge of recovering it, for fear the Remedy prove worse than the Di●…e.

sp.speaker: She.
sp.p: C●…e, no more, let's be Friends— I'll step and see if the Door be open.— Here, Starter, take the Warrant, but stay till. I re●…. [Exit.

sp.speaker: 2 Bayl.
sp.p: Thou wert very close with him Ieoffry, I would not have said so much to ' un for a Hundred good pounds.

sp.speaker: 3 Bayl.
sp.p: Nor I neither.

sp.speaker: 1 Bayl.
sp.p: Because like a parcel of Spaniels you love to be under— but to our businss.

sp.speaker: 2 Bayl.
sp.p: Ay, by all means let's mind that.

sp.speaker: 1 Bayl.
sp.p: First then this is a common Original Process.

sp.speaker: 4 Bayl.
sp.p: Good sweet now, out of which a Court comes thick a Writ? I never he●…d on before.

sp.speaker: 1 Bayl.
sp.p: You Blunderheads, 'tis only a bare Arrest.

sp.speaker: 4 Bayl.
sp.p: That's well a fine.

sp.speaker: 1 Bayl.
sp.p: 〈◊〉. Hum— Hum— Ieoffry Starter. Here I am in mine own proper Person; Vous avis, Mr. Starter. Alexander Squeez.

sp.speaker: 2 Bayl.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: 1 Bayl.
sp.p: V●…us ●…is; Rowland Spurge.

sp.speaker: 3. Bayl.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: 1. Bayl.
sp.p: Vous avis; Timothy Thoroughstich.

sp.speaker: 1 Bayl.
sp.p: Vous avis vertute brevis Domini Regis— Hu. Hu. Mando quod capiatis Anthium Swash Ar. Hu. hu. [Hums to himself]— Ita quod habeam corpus ejus coram Iustic' dicti Domini Regis apud Westm, a die Paschae in quindecim dies— ad respondend Patricio Gredio Mil' de placito debit. super demand Mille librax— Et hoc, &c. Dat. Sub Sigillo Officii mei, &c. very well.

sp.speaker: 2 Bayl.
sp.p: That's more than we know, read loud in English that we may understand it.

sp.speaker: 1 Bayl.
sp.p: I read it as it is; 'Twill puzzle some Attornies to read in true English.

sp.speaker: Shuffle.
sp.p: Away Boys, the Door's open, the old Fox is generally the first that moves, stay all in the Entry between the Doors till I give you the Sign, for you must cross the Room where we shall be discoursing.

sp.speaker: 1 Bayl.
sp.p: As soon as you have turned his Back towards the Door, give the Hint, we know our parts; away before, we follow. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II. Gripe's House.

sp.speaker: Shuffle.
sp.p: Wait there for the Sign— Now for Impudence and a good Memory, that I be not found in a Lye.

div.p: He comes— Pray, Sir, are you Mr. Gripe the rich Merchant?

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: What would you Friend?— My name is Gripe.

sp.speaker: Shuffle.
sp.p: I have a Letter for you requires haste. [Delivers a Letter.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: 'Tis Spalding's Hand.

sp.speaker: Shufflle.
sp.p: It works, his colour comes and goes— Hist! Hist! [The Sign given, the four Bayliffs cross the Stage.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: You come from Stephen Spalding.

sp.speaker: Shuffle.
sp.p: I did so; and for better dispatch, I have travelled all this night on my bare Feet, I am all over like toasted Cheese.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: But you needed not to have made so much haste, Bad News flies fast enough of it self.

sp.speaker: Shuffle.
sp.p: Captain Spalding told me it requir'd extraordinary speed, and would not suffer me to stay so long as to put on my best Clathers.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: He always was a trusty Servant— But is the Work so poor as he Writes?

sp.speaker: Shuffle.
sp.p: I know not what he Writes, but I'm certain he'll be forced to strike it in the Head with speed.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: So he Writes me— What store of work have you at Hill? and what at Mill?

sp.speaker: Shuffle.
sp.p: What can I tell— Who thought of this damn'd Question? [Aside.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: He Writ me lately he had a great quantity at each place.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: There is so; but we are forc'd to put most of our men to Spalding, and to Buddles.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: What store of Tails, Casualties, and Afterwashes have ye?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Heap enough, but how 'twill yield as yet I know not; we imploy all the Stamps and Buddles about the Head-Tinn, we shall have time enough to work the leavings.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: How do you proceed at the Blowing-house?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: A Plague of these Questions. [Aside.] We have Tinn there, Sir, and good, as much as it is, tho' it don't yield as well as formerly.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Ha! your Reason for that.

sp.speaker: Shuffle.
sp.p: I suppose when things begin to decay they are not so full of Mettle: I have no other Reason, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: 'Tis a sad Truth, I know it by woful experience— How far distant is this rich Mine from ours? can't you sink a Shaft on the edge of our Bounds, and drive under them? I'd venture my life to have a share in it: May not their Load incline towards us? It does not run North and South? Mine lies due West as I take it?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Exactly, Sir, North and South; I went down into their Work, measured with the Compass, and the Load runs exactly with the Ely.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: And so wondrous rich!

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: They suffered me to break a Stone my self, of part I made a Van, and 'twas all perfect Tinn— I think I have a piece in my Pocket— [Gives a Stone. If he know it, I'm undone, Sharper stole it out of his Parlour Window. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Never stir! 'tis very like mine.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: But richer: One of the Eastern Tryers whispered me, that all the dizzo was excellent Copper, and that he would give a 1000 l. for what is in sight.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Bless me! and ours worth nothing?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Not one Dram of Mettle left in all your bottoms.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Undone, undone! inevitably ruined!— I shall want Bread.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Content your self, you have enough, and supposing the worst, you may buy up as much Black-Tinn as you please, and that commonly turns to a good Accompt at the Coinage.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Twenty per Cent. for 3 Months; A Man can't live by it.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Captain Spalding sent me Express, that you might endeavour to get a Dole, or Set, before Mr. Manley's intelligence comes from Captain Buddle.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Which shall be done (if possible)— Who comes here— [Enter Starter pulling Sharp.] What rudeness is this in my House.

sp.speaker: 1 Bayl.
sp.p: Rudeness, I come with a Posse Comitatis in my Pocket.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Who do you look for?

sp.speaker: 〈◊〉 Bayl.
sp.p: One Squire Swash; I have a Priviledge Warrant again him.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p:
Then you are mistaken, this is one Mr. Sharper— Now will I take this opportunity to Cashier Swash, and Marry her to Manley at last;
He is a very honest Gentleman, that's the truth on't, and I think it is a just Judgment for designing to cheat him of her; but I'll amend all.

div.stage: Enter Squeeze, Spunge, and Thorowstitch, pulling in Swash.

sp.speaker: 3 Bail.
sp.p: Along with him, roage him along, he shall to prison immediately,

sp.speaker: 1 Bail.
sp.p: Be more merciful to him, he will answer the Law quietly, Squire I will be your Guard.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: 'Tis a very hard Law if it give you Liberty to tear the Flesh from the Bones.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Pray Gentlemen let us discourse the matter fairly, At whose suit do you Arrest my Master.

sp.speaker: 3 Bai.
sp.p: Sir Patrick Greedy, 'tis an Action of Scandalum Magnatum for a Thousand Pound Debt.

sp.speaker: 4 Bai.
sp.p: And there's a Mandamus, a Capias, and Habeas Corpus in the Warrant, and Law enough to carry him to the other end of the King's Bench-Rules.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Indeed, Gentlemen, I don't owe that Knight one Farthing.

sp.speaker: 1 Bai.
sp.p: Then it will be the better for you, Sir,— You may try it, and the Jury may acquit you, so you have your remedy; but as the case stands, you must give us good Bail in 2000 l. as the Law requires, or go to Prison. I am heartily sorry for your condition, and wish it lay in my power to do you any service, but the Law is such we can't help it.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: We'll give you Bail as the Law requires, this day he is to Marry Mr. Gripe's Daughter, I suppose the Father and Son will be his Bail.

sp.speaker: 1 Ba.
sp.p: We'l take 'em.

sp.speaker: Gr. Pray,
sp.p: Mr. Sharper, mind your own business, and trouble not your head about other People, I nor my Son don't intend to be Ingaged for any Man; we that take Bonds don't use to enter into them— a timely discovery, I had been finely chous'd had he Married my Daughter. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Pray, Gentlemen, let me go, within a little time I shall be going to Church to be Married, let me have one night's Lodging, to morrow I'll surrender my self; 'twould make a man mad to lose all between the Cup and the Lip.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Trouble not your self for that, Sir,— I shall provide another Husband for my Daughter, my Money shall never go to pay Debts.

sp.speaker: 1 Bai.
sp.p: Away with him, What stand we here for? If you have any Gentleman to send for, we'l ' stay a while at Nich Froths; 'tis pity such a fine Gentleman should be in trouble, but 'tis no fault of ours.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Carry me where you will, I am careless how the world goes,— Sharper, Why dost weep?

sp.speaker: Sharper.
sp.p: To see so good a Master so inhumanly used, 'twill break my heart to see you in Prison; never had good Gentleman such bad fortune. [Sharper weeps.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Prithe don't weep, thou makes me melancholy to see thee— poor fellow! he loves me dearly. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I'll never leave you whilst I have Life or Limb. [Exit with Swash and Bailiffs.

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: Have you any service to command me to Captain Spalding?

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: These accidents have so disordered me, I know not what to resolve on— step in and call my Daughter hither— but here she comes with her Brother. Enter Peregrine and Clarinda dressed like a Bride. Thou art early trimn●…d for Wedlock my Clarinda; how Gay! a Match is no 〈◊〉 agreed on, and the Wedding appointed, but the Woman is so taken up with the thoughts of the time to come, that she never resteth till her fancy be fulfill'd.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: My Father talking thus to himself! I doubt he is not well.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: I vow I am very wantonly inclin'd this morning, and feel a tickling in my Veins like a Boy of Twenty,— Hey! sound and hearty yet! oh! for a sprightly Young Girl to comfort my Old Spirits, I would give her a broad side, and launch into the deep— Ha! (never stir)! that word hath put me in mind of my Tinnwork again, now on a sudden am I become as cold and as dull as a Bridegroom after the first week,— therefore exit Love, and enter Business.— You Fellow withdraw, I would have some private Conference with my Son and Daughter. [Exit Shuff.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Are you not well, dear Father? You seem much discomposed.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: So would'st thou, had'st thou a Daughter to dispose of; she must be Married— and she must not be Married— she shall be Married, and she shall not be Married— I don't know what to do with her.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: So unsettl'd and unresolv'd, you would make me think you were in a frenzy.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Yes, fellows of your Age always think their Fathers Mad till they are Buried.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let me know the disquiets of your mind.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Wilt thou assist me?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Sir, to the hazard of my Life, I will.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: I know not how to bestow thy Sister.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Is she not this day to be Married to the Squire Swash? You told her so last evening.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: My Passion, Sir, submitting to my Duty, I am all Obedience to your positive Commands.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Good! if a man promise these wanton Rogues a Husband, they'll be sure to call him to an account for a strict performance— [Aside]. Manley, at last, must Marry thee, Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Then you abuse the Noble Squire.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: She pleads for him— I was to blame to raise her expectation; if they have sealed the Bargain by an Ante nuptial Fornication, I have finely studied the Politicks,— [Aside].— Swash is carried away to Prison by Four Bailiffs, therefore he must not Marry thee.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I am sorry for that, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: What makes thee sorry, ha?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: My Charity.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Charity! 'tis thy folly, by some called good nature, which brings folks to Beggery; no, thou ne'er shalt Marry that Fop as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Sir, I heartily thank your Promise, and here I make a solemn Vow, I never will be his Wife.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Clarinda, you must now renew all your Charms, and strive by Words and Actions to reclaim Manley: Your attractive faculty hath force enough to reduce him.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: With scorns and slights he hath been so provoked, I doubt the task will prove too difficult for my weak power.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Love abused turns to hatred, Clarinda must walk warily.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Let her alone; dissimulation, especially in love-affairs, is a vertue inherent to that Sex; I know his Temper, give him a fair opportunity, and my life he takes it; therefore omit no artifice that may reclaim him; I would not for the world lose this happy Match; I am now so far from being jealous of thee, that I heartily wish you were a Bed together.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: And that may be before you are aware. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Oh, my dear Clarinda! little think'st thou what pains, what fears, what doubts, what jealousies, we careful Parents labour under, to bestow our Children well,— may thy designs and undertakings prosper.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Pray Heaven it end so well! [Aside.

div.stage: Enter Trusty, Manley, Eugenia, Freeman, as to the Wedding.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: My Friends and Neighbours, a hearty welcome to you all.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: We thank you, Sir.— Madam, a good day.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: The same attend you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Well said, Clarinda, thou art my own Flesh and Blood,— how they stare and gaze!— ay, ay, 'tis so, their hearts are renewing acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The Bride's prepared for Marriage, Where is the Bridegroom?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Not far, since you are here.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: That's my Jewel,— that was a bold stroke, and home to the purpose, I wonder the phlegmatick Dog doth not leap at the bait; time was when I would have made better use of such an opportunity; I fear he has heard the news, and so draws off.

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: By your leave Gentlemen, Is one Mr. Manley here?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: My Name is Manley.

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: I have a Letter for you. [Delivers a Letter.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: 'Tis Budele's hand. [Opens and Reads.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: It is his intelligence; this is the beginning of my ruin; I have not yet made my Bargain, and now my Daughter will be left upon my hands. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: This for the Postage— bring confirmation, I ask no more of Fortune,— Sir, Will you see it? [Gives Money. Gives the Leteer to Trusty.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Beyond imagination! a rich Load cut but Two days since, and yesterday a hundred load at Grass! I never heard the like success.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: The poor Labourers kill themselves. Oh, pity, pity I [Aside.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Good news from your Tinn-work, Sir, I joy in the success.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir,— but your Father hath ill fortune, for which I am sorry.

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: I'll in and uncase for fear of a discovery— [Aside.]— [Exit.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: I can no longer hear this discourse; here is no Wedding to day, nor like to be with Squire Swash, which may prove to the advantage of some one present, if he please to understand it. Clarinda make your Friends wellcome, I'll in and cool my self, and then dispatch my Letters. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You see my Father begins to be reconciled. [Smiling.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I'll after, and invite him to the wedding.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: You then destroy your Sister's Match; 'tis dangerous medling with a Lion till he be securely chained: You match to day, they stay but one day longer; out of a vehement desire of revenge he shall devest himself of all to Peregrine.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: and my fidelity to the fair Eugenia need not be mistrusted.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Young Men are ever constant till they have a fairer purchase, or a better opportunity.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Away, you lose time, the Parson is ready to say Grace,— Mr. Freeman, I must desire your Company at Nich Froths immediately after Dinner, you may be serviceable to my Nephew.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I shall not fail, mean while I must to my Captain Busy.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Come, Parson, are you ready?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: The Canonical Hour is pass'd, you must stay till to morrow.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I understand you. [Gives him Money; the Parson looks on and fingers his Watch.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Hum! indeed I was mistaken,— a Quarter past Eleven; I'll do your business immediately in the next room.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And may we constant each to other prove, As now Uniting by the power of Love.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Curtain drawn, discovers Swash and Sharper at Cribbidge; four Bailiffs and Nich. Froth sitting by Smoaking and Drinking. News Papers on the Table.

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.p: COme Boys; we squander the time; the Squire's Health. Ten Pound on your Worship's Game. [Drinks.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Two for Noddy; that's well. [Turns and puts up

sp.speaker: 1 Bail.
sp.p: That turn made your Game. Three to One of the Squire's Game.

sp.speaker: 2 Bail.
sp.p: Lawk ye! Will you so? The Squire hath three Shows for twelve Holes: Mr. Sharper must carry Fifteen this time, or he's gone.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: As I am a living Man I am but Eight. [Puts up.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: I am Six; play away: I have but Six more to go. [Puts up.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I play the Ten of Diamonds. [Plays.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Now must he have a Knave and a Five in his Hand: If I play my Nine, he'll take Second's: I'll venture: Twenty and a Pair. [Puts up.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: To put it out of dispute, there's a Pair-Royal, and the single Game. Seven for that. I am out, Sir. [Puts up.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: The Devil take the Cards: Who wou'd ha' thought 'em all out! I had two Tens and a Nine; that was my Six.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Two Tens and a Five, and a Knave turn'd, made me Eight. Will you play again, Sir?

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Fortune is against me to day.— Give me a Glass of Ale.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: And the best in the Country. Here's a Tankard of Bottled-Ale out of the Cask.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Thy meaning?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Thus, Sir: First, I Brew mine Ale; then I Wort mine A●…e; then I tun mine Ale; when it is fine, I Bottle mine Ale, closely stopp'd; after a Fornight, I take Bottle after Bottle, and pour it into a fine clean Cask, leaving the Sedement in every Bottle. This fine Drink I keep for Gentlemen of Quality, and my best Customers.

sp.speaker: 4 Bail.
sp.p: He'll make 'em believe the Moon's made of Green Cheese.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: If ordinary Fellows will have it, they pay me Six pence the Quart, Gentlemen Four pence. Let who will be for Gain, I stand on the Credit and Reputation of my House: I have Six Hogsheads of this fine Liquor in my Cellar.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Give me a Glass: It looks and tastes like Small Beer. [Drinks.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Would you have it like the sedementary Ale, thick, heavy, fulsom, phlegmatick, nasty stuff, fit only for Hedgers and Threshers? This my Chimical Preparation is healthy and sound for the Body, the Quintessence of Rarefaction.

sp.speaker: 1 Bail.
sp.p: But, Landlord, (takes him aside) what Methods do you intend in managing the Reckoning? We will swear for thee.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Is he well lin'd?

sp.speaker: 1 Bail.
sp.p: No doubt on't.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Then, as my Friends, I'll trust you with my Secrets: In the beginning, when Gentlemen are cool, I always reckon 5 for 4; if catch'd, I and my Wife fall to scolding; with a submissive Apology I crave pardon for the Disturbance, and acknowledge the Mistake: The Gentlemen are appeas'd, I call for my Quart, drink their Healths, swear there was never such an Accident in my House before, and that I'll watch my Maid's Water for the future.

sp.speaker: 1 Bail.
sp.p: You still hold to the proportion of 5 for 4?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: No; as they inflame their Noddles, I the Reckonings; 4 for 3, 3 for 2, and at last 2 for 1; but I never go beyond, unless they have been entred in my Wife's Book; and then 3 for 1 is very reasonable.

sp.speaker: 1 Bail.
sp.p: Suppose such a Trick should be discover'd?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: When all are drunk, there can be no Mistake; or if such a Discovery were possible, I was drunk; and paying my Forfeiture next Morning, it passeth current again. These Doctrines I learnt when I was a Drawer up in the City: I intended to put up a Tavern here in the Country; but finding the Wine-Drinkers crowding to London; and the others not able to go to the Cost, I set up an honest Ale-house, as you see.

sp.speaker: 1 Bail.
sp.p: I did not think there had been so much Art.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Our Profession is a meer Mystery; but above all we need understand Arithmetick well; for Substraction and Division are as requisite in the Measures, as Addition and Multiplication in the Reckonings; and all compacted together, teach you the Golden Rule.— So, perge Mentiri, let every one follow his own Trade. [Exit.

div.stage: [All this while Swash and Sharper at Cards.
Enter Trusty and Freeman at each Door.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: Having Marry'd my lovely Pair, and divided 'em till Night with further Instructions, now for my Woodcock in his Trap.— Freeman! well met.— How now, Squire! here so late on your Wedding Day? I expected to have seen you at, I Anthony take thee Clarinda, long e're this.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: But Poor Tony's Policy is quite out of doors; to be snatch'd away in the Flower of my Youth, in the height of mine Appetite, a delicate fine Dish prepar'd and set before me, and not suffer'd to take one Taste, is a damn'd, cursed Misfortune.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: You have but raskally Company about you, Sir: What mean these Catchpoles?

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Trusty, the saddest Story ever was heard! As I was going to be Marry'd, I was Marr'd to all intents and purposes; the Devil, in the shape of Four of his Children, laid violent hands on me, and brought me here in a Surprize!

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p:
On a meer Fob-Action; 'tis a damn'd Cheat; he doth not owe a Penny to any Man alive: Wou'd he were hang'd that invented such a
piece of Roguery against such a good Gentleman! O damn'd Villains! [Weeps.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Thou art so moody hearted, thou makest me weep for Company— I believe never was a Man more happy in a Servant.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: To lose so Sweet! so Young! so Beautiful a Mistress!—

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: And honest Trey and Cater thy Fellow-Servants.—

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: This looks very suspicious, Gentlemen, have you good Law for what you do?

sp.speaker: 1 Bail.
sp.p: Yes, you may see if you please.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: It grieves me to the heart to see a Gentleman abus'd. I'll be his Bail.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: And I, if the Bailiff will take us.

sp.speaker: 1 Bail.
sp.p: We will; we are not scrupulous.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: I know the Old Gentleman will indemnifie me.— The Noble Squire shan't to Prison on such a Fob-Action. [Hugs him.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I vow, Gentlemen, this is a great Kindness you do my Master.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Is it? It is; in trouble and thrall, Man; I shall never never make 'em satisfaction while I live. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Trust.
