sp.p: No more words; in, in, that we may discharge you: I'll stay but one minute.— Freeman, put the Glass merrily round; I'll bring a sudden Reprieve. [Exeunt all but Trusty and Shuffle. Now, my dear Shuffle, how go matters now?

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: Ill enough; all the Design is frustrated: Spalding is return'd, and denies the whole matter; the old Gripe rants like a Mad-man; hath sent an Express to Sir Patrick Greedy, to know if he will own the Action; swears 'tis all your work to cheat him of his Child.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: Let the procrastinating Fop vex and torment himself to death; spight of his Care I'll cheat him of both his Children, his Estate and Money too.

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: Peregrine turns tail, hath ingratiated himself, and his Father will settle all upon him; which the old Man hath granted, and hath given Orders to have the Deeds drawn: He vows Clarinda shall not have one Groat, unless she marry Swash to morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: This succeeds as I would wish.— Who draws the Deed?

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: Peregrine desired me; but I would not promise, without your Consent.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: We must trust him— (Aside.) be sure you tie him fast, and you must hasten it.

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: I'll fetter him; not all the Power of Law shall e'er release him: I'll bribe Cunningame the Attorney to be of our side; he is his Idol; what he says goes down with him without suspicion. Have you any other Service to command me? I was told Mr. Freeman hath Business with me.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: He's in the next Room; I'll send him out immediately. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: Mr. Freeman's Business I guess is of another nature; some Wench with Child to be provided for; so that I must be Pimp-Broker: This is somewhat scandalous to the Profession; but there is Money to be got; so that's answer'd.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Shuffle, I have a little Secret to impart to thee, wherein I want thy Assistance: Thou shalt be well paid, I promise thee.

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: And that you know is the Life of all Trades: You are no Stranger, I have had much of your Money; whate'er it be I'll do it, and trust your Generosity. Come, declare; some common Flesh hath been so long blown upon, that living Creatures begin to move.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: Even so; she at Nich. Froth's, that goes under the Character of a Relation.

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: She hath been your Hackney long enough; 'tis time to procure a Chapman, and march her off.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: Such a one I have: Captain Busy, thou shalt appear before her as her Steward, whilst I, under the same Title of a Relation, bring him to over-hear you pass your Accompts.

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: Good: Being already train'd to his hand, she'll the sooner understand his Exercise.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: I have some Bags of Nails shall lie before you on the Table, with Money in their mouths. Disguise thy self: I'll leave the rest to thee.

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: And no longer Shuffle, but Mr. Abraham Rentall, Madam Freeman's Steward, with some old Bonds and Deeds, will meet you an Hour hence at this place; I suppose she's sufficiently instructed.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: Yes; all things shall be ready.

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: I question not your care; and I'll perform my part, with assured success and expedition.
sp.l: To hide the Shame, and get Estate for Life,
My pregnant Miss must be a Captains's Wife. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.p:
Mr. Freeman, a word with you. He is gone to the Company: I thought to have had him speak one word of Reconcilement for me to my Wife; he can work what he pleases upon her. When I first set up here in the Country, I Marry'd a handsom Girl, who according to expectation, proved a compleat, tempting, hypocritical Jilt; I the necessary Perquisite, a good-natur'd Landlord, otherwise call'd a spunging, insinuating, contented Cuckold. We are both Cheats; so far 'tis right and well. According to the Quality of my Function, my Wife takes all upon her. Any Man would think such Dealings would satisfie her; but I vow she's grown very obstreperous and ungrateful; for
even now going to the Barr to see how the Reckoning stood, I met our Servant-Maid; the Spirit being willing, the Flesh and the Devil prevailing, I was very loving; the poor innocent Creature blushing, cry'd, Nay, pish!— Nay, fye!— Mistress is coming— I'll vow I'll cry out! yet all the while kiss'd as close as any Cockle: In the nick of time comes the Devil of a Wife, and disturb'd us: My little Magpye squeak'd, and thrust me from her, but whisper'd I should meet her in the Summer-House at Nine this Evening; which certainly I'll do, for all your Frumps, Mrs Sus.— Ay, there she is coming; I must march, or woe to my Bones!

div.p: Anon, Sir; by and by; a coming, Sir. [As he is going, she takes him by the Arm.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Why in such haste? there's no body calls.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Indeed, Wife, I thought the Gentlemen had knock'd.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: You are very nimble with your Attendance; you were not so an Hour since: The Gentlemen knock'd and call'd, and no Landlord to be found, till uncivilly I was forc'd to rise from my Cushion, and leave their Company to fetch Liquor.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: What will become of me!— Indeed, Wife, I did not hear 'em; upon my Word I did not.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: No, you were otherwise employ'd with your Servant-Maid; you were so.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: I was only teaching her her Business, how to cast up the Reckoning.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: You were teaching her to be a Strumpet— There was hugging and kissing, and other things in hand, had not I timely prevented.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: I whisper'd her, that if she knew the Gentlemen to be Customers to you, she must reckon three for one.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Consider, Sirrah, who I am, and whence I came; my Father, a good Farmer, bred me the next Degree to a Gentlewoman, else I could ne'er ha' made so good a Landlady: 'Tis for the love of me there's such resort; 'tis I who keep the Door open, Sirrah! How oft have I been forc'd to watch whole Nights to give my Guests content and satisfaction, and all to make thee rich; whilst thou keepest Wenches Company, and cheatest me of that Love is only due to me.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, if I increase in Duty by deputation an hundred-fold, you are no loser: How many times have I, with the Eye of Judgment, seen things which shall be nameless, touching my Freehold; yet putting on the Mask of charitable Unbelief, have quietly sate down in the Chair of Contentment, and said nothing?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Nay, since thou art grown so hardy to justifie thy own Actions, and to tax my courteous and civil Deportment to my Customers, I'll make thee know what 'tis to abuse one that gives so creditable Entertainment. [Beats (him.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: How now, Wife! where is your Cherishing and Obedience?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Vanish'd with your Bodily Worship, Sirrah. [Beats him.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Good, dear Wife, I'll do so no more.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Not till next time; once a Villain, and always so. [Beats him.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Here on my Knees, with lifted Hands, and unfeigned penitential Tears, I offer up my Vows to the Altar of Love and the Shrine of Matrimony. [Kneels and prays.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: I'll sacrifice thee to my Revenge.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Anon, anon, Sir; by and by; coming. [Runs out.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: H'ath quite tir'd me; yet I have paid him sufficiently: An impudent Beast, that can't show natural Civility to his Wife, yet should think to be modish! By threats I have made the Wench confess their Appointment; I'll meet him my self, and try what may be done.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: What, my kind Landlady, and arm'd for Battel!

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: When Husbands break their Matrimonial Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy, they deserve severe Correction.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: Lay no such Fault on thine; he's as quiet and harmless Fellow as lives; I'll vouch for him.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Because you are so sweet, so civil, so good-natur'd, you think all others so: Were he a Person of your generous Spirit, I should be the happiest Woman living; but to be so us'd by that empty Thing, that meer Shadow of a Husband, (conceive me, Mr. Freeman) is unsufferable.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: What is the matter? And why this Cudgel?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: To chastise my Husband: I caught him about an Hour since (conceive me) debauching my Maid; but I have corrected him, and have another way to lay the Evil Spirit (conceive me, Mr. Freeman) if he be again possest.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: You will prepare Things for Margaret, as you promis'd.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: She and the Maids are ready drest, all Things prepar'd: Can I forget what my dear Mr. Freeman doth require me!

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: So, that's well.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Methinks I am always ravish'd with your Company.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: How! ravish'd?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Charm'd! bewitch'd!— I know not what to call it! Conceive me; but am never quiet but in your Company.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: So; I have brought my self int●… fine Premunire! There's another within will weep, if she han't all the fine Things. Flesh and Blood on't hold; I am meerly metamorphis'd already; I must submit to Self-denial, because I can enjoy the Pleasures of the World no longer. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: I dreamt last night, that Mr. Freeman came to my Bed-side, hugg'd me, kist me, prest me; so sweet! so delicate! so pleasing! (Conceive me, Mr. Freeman.)

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: A very comfortable Relation! [Aside.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: 'Tis an Age since I saw you last! I can tell you the prettiest Story,— In t'other Room 'tis warmer (conceive me, Mr. Freeman)

div.stage: [Takes him by the hand, loading him out.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: Or we shall make it so.— Now for some Relief for the Forlorn Hope.

div.stage: Enter Trusty and Swash, and others.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: In private with Mr. Freeman!— What think you of this Landlord?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: I dare not tell you, Sir; I am deaf and blind; but I hope 'tis no Treason to think— Tho she be rude with me, other People can keep in with her: A time will come to revenge all these Evils.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Sharper, how goes the Day?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: The Clock struck Four, about half an Hour ago.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: We'll to the Cock-pit; I'll Fight 'em presently: My Cocks Fight as well by Candle as Day-light: You know the Wager, Three Battels for 300 Pound.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: And shake Bag-Law: We are ready to attend you.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: What have we to pay, Landlord?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: 'Tis my Wife's Element; I keep nothing from her.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Two Pounds Two Shillings and Two pence half-penny to a Farthing.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Here are two Guineas; I take no Change; but first a Song and Dance.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: Mr. Freeman, You will go with us?

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: You must excuse me, Sir; I have somewhat of the like nature on my hands.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: Success to both.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: The Bailiffs are paid?

sp.speaker: 1 Bail.
sp.p: Yes, Noble Squire●…▪

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: There's to drink my Health.
sp.l: Sharper hath cunningly my Friends betray'd:
We'll get their Money first, and then the Maid. [Exeunt▪

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Courtain drawn, discovers Margaret sitting at a Table; two Waiting-Maids behind the Chair; Bags, Deeds, and Bonds on the Table; Shuffle at the other end with Pen, Ink, and Paper.
Enter Freeman, Busy standing at the entrance of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: A lucky Minute, her Steward is passing his Accompts; let's wait and overhear 'em.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: Great and mighty Bags! She must be wondrous rich, if all that be Interest.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: And Rents: She hath a great Estate, as well as Money.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: A Portly Lady; and a great Beauty.

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: Item, Your Barton and Mannor of Coorrowda, in the County of Carmarthan, given your Ladyship by the last Will and Testament of Sir Frederick Harding Knight, Citizen and Merchant of London, your Honours Grand-father, Rents per Annum 200 l. received 150 l. remains in Arrears 50 l.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: By stealing of Custom, and a false Oath at the Custom-House, after the end of every Voyage, and if his Wife were right (as we say) ten to one but some Court-Blood runs in her Veins.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: What mean you, Captain?

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: From the borrowing Lord there lies an Obligation to the Creditors Wife, she is Complemented with the Interest to buy Pins, and then she hath the opportunity to shew her Civility, when his Lordship is pleased to honour her with the particular marks of his Favour.

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: Item, Your Mannor and Barton of in the County of the Gift of your Brother-in-Law, Doctor Bunting, a Civilian, Rent per Annum 80 l. Receiv'd 60 l. Rests 20 l.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: The Common Lawyers devour the Body and Estate, the Spiritual Court the Soul: Tho' the Locusts grow fast, but few of them prosper in the Third or Fourth Generation.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: At this rate Captain, you'll abuse the whole Nation.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: Who can forbear to make Remarks upon such a Gallimawfxy Family?

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: Here is a Bond of 1000 l. Principal, due to your Honour from the Executors of Arthur Hadland Esq Deceased.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Take care the Security be good.

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: 'Tis very good indeed Madam, and the Interest well paid.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: I was Acquainted with that Gentleman, a Justice of Peace, but had no more Law than his Clerk infused.

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: So much Madam for your Welsh Mannors, and Bartons Rents per Annum of the whole 1500 l. in these two Bags 1000 l. remains in Arrear in the Tenants hands 500 l.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: See it be well Secured.

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: They would have paid in the whole, if I would have received Guineas for 23. but were loath to part with 'em for less. Of your Plantations in America, I expect an account every Ship, and a Bill of the Free-income from the Correspondents.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: The yearly value?

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: Communibus Annis 600 l. Received for Interest of 4000 l. at 6 per Cent. 240 l. in that Bag, the Interest for 2000 l. in the Debtors hand.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: See it suddenly paid, or call in the principal, and see the whole be well secured.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: I can no longer forbear, prithee Lieutenant break in upon her out guards, if I can storm her Trenches, I'll raise a Battery, and force my Entrance, or Bomb her till I make her surrender Bag and Baggage.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Fear not Captain we'll make her yeild, tho' I assure you, you'll find more in her than you are aware of, but no matter, 'twill all be discovered in time to your advantage.— Niece, I have brought a Gentleman to see you.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Whoever comes with you is doubly welcome.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: Nay then, Courage, fall on,— Madam your Slave— A brave plump Wench, and kisseth rarely. I'll warrant her a delicate Bedfellow in a Frosty Morning. Salutes her.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: I doubt (Neice) we have disturbed you.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: No, no dear Sir, my Steward being returned from keeping my Courts, I had a mind to learn what he had done; I think 'twas almost over, Rent all.

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: To a small matter.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Leave it to some other opportunity.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: To what a Mass of Wealth and Honour am I growing. (Aside

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: This Gentleman, my Worthy, Honourable Friend, is come to kiss your Hand, and if he Court you, Treat him Civilly; I am desirous he should be your Husband.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: Well said Lieutenant, he doth not beat about the Bush, but falls immediately upon the point, and since 'tis so well begun, now for Lies and Flatteries in abundance. (Aside)— Fame, Madam, having talked so loud in your praise, I had a greedy desire to view the Original, imparting this to your Uncle, he brought me hither, and now I find, what I have heard comes short of what I see; Mine Eyes no sooner saw, but my Heart was in a Flame, it heaves, it beats, it trembles, I'm all over Pulse, and in a perfect Agony.— The Devils in't, if this be not expressed like a true Lover. Aside.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: The Woodcock comes on apace. Aside.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I doubt Sir, you are more in love with what you heard, than what you fee.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: She is in the right of it; tho' I must pretend otherwise. (Aside No, Madam, no; tho' what I heard is much beyond my poor deserts, 'tis you, 'tis only you, your Person I adore.— Know I abhor that petty, paltry Pelf, let it be gone, all vanish into Air. Let my Dear Love, my Saint, my Idol be only Armed Cap A Pe with nakedness.— Tho' I say it my self, and tho' it be a damned Lye, 'twas a lively expression, I Appeal to any Man that understands Courtship and Lying. (Asid●…▪

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I Vow 'tis a pretty Gentleman. Seemingly aside.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: Is he so? (Aside)— I love you Madam, beyond all the World, from these fair Eyes, these Ruby, charming Lips, I Panting wait my doom.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Oh! were it true he says.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p:
True, Madam! Is it the Sun that Rules the Day? The Moon and Stars that Guide the Night? 'Tis easier to make the high Alps Navigable,
or stop the raging motions of the Winds or Seas, than to divert or rather quench my Love.— Oh my Dear Saint, didst thou but know the secret Flames within my Breast do glow, you would not be so cruel, so hard hearted.— She trembles. He takes her by the hand.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Oh! I am lost. Falls into a Swoon.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: Captain you are fortunate, the Fort is won.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: If I had her in private I'de quickly bring her to her right Senses.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: She revives again: How do ye Neice?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: A Devil Gnaws and Tears my Breast.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: 'Tis a very good natured Devil, he is pleading my Cause, this is the first Service he ever did me.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: Come, come you can no longer hide it, I see you love the Captain.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I know not; but I find I cannot hate him.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: Take her; to Morrow she shall be your Bride.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: Which Gift I joyfully receive.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I am all obedient to my Uncles Pleasure, but why so sudden? I have no new Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.l: No matter, we put'em all off when we go to Bed.
'Tis better far than seven years a Cooing,
Billing and other formal acts of Wooing;
Blest is the Match that is not long a doing.

div.head: SCENE III. A Garden.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: I have locked up my young Rival in her Chamber; there let her wallow on her Bed in Meditation, whilst I receive my due; a ripe Age this, that a Girl not past fifteen, should pretend to years of Discretion, and with my Husband too, what will this World come to?— Well, I'll go and defeat his expectations. A Rascal debauch his own Maid. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Swash in his Wastcoat and Drawers.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p:
All lost, all gone; my Mistress, my Money, my Cloaths, and Sharper has left me: No Friend to a Man in Adversity. All my Jewels
Sacrificed, Cut-throat, Fencer, Warriour, Dangerfield, and the rest of their Honourable and Worthy Brethren, disfigured, and by Treachery, put one against the other, and all in Battel slain, the whole Generation, Root and Branch, cut off in the prime of their years; Trey and Cater murthered, I had as good go home and hang all the Hounds, and make a clear House.— 'Tis wondrous dark, I must endeavour to find out my way to some lodging. Exit the same way.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Now for my Assignation with my little Harlot, and now Madam Susanna, I stand in defiance of your Cudgel; if variety be so good, 'tis necessary I sometimes humour my nice Pallate, I will therefore Solace my self in change of Love.— But hold Nicholas, look before you leap; suppose in the abundance of thy Affection, she should Conceive, and should have issue by thee? thy Wife Susanna will Confiscate thee to all Intents and Purposes.— A bad business I'll go no further.— But hold sweet Nicholas, one word more, thy little Damosel of Delight, now in the Cold expecting thee, should she grow Sick and Die, by this disappointment— The case is altered again, therefore I will proceed— What tho' there be a Child or Children, of the Body of the said Nicholas Froth, upon the Body of his said Servant Maid, begotten or to be begotten.— She shall name no Father, and some of my Wives Customers shall pay for the maintenance; or what if it pass for Nicholas Froth's Child? All these things impartially considered: a decree passeth, that I stand firmly to my first resolutions; may it therefore please your Ladyship, Mrs. Wife, to excuse my personal attendance for the present. (Exit. Swash meets him, he starts back in a fright. Ha! The Devil! I see his Cloven Foot, he hath been before me, and made the first cut in the Pye— Had I disturbed him, he had certainly torn me pieces— O poor Creature thou art finely pepper'd.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Searching my way, and opening a little Door, I entred, and immediately a Woman with her Arms clapped me about the Neck, I soon found it a Banquet of Love prepared for another Man, without saying Grace I fell too, to her satisfaction as well as mine own I hope— However this is some Comfort in the midst of my troubles. (Exit.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Is he gone? He hath cooled my courage, yet I am in a Sweat, he talked, methoughts, very merrily, therefore I judge he hath been playing the Rogue, what a brave opportunity have I lost, curs'd disappointment!

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: My Nicholas is a very kind Husband upon occasion; but why he went off so soon, I cannot imagine: Certainly he could not discover me— I hear some one one tread— Who's there?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Ha!— Sus!— Now have I been Cuckolded by the Devil! If she hath conceiv'd, I hope she'll ne'er bring forth: 'Twill be a sad case if I must Father a young Beelzebub in mine old Age. (Aside.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Who's there? Nicholas!

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Sus! what makes you here so late?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: To keep you honest against your will, Friend, you took me for another in the Garden-house— so brisk! so fine! so amorous! I have discover'd you now in the height of your Roguery; you thought, like a filthy Fellow, to have found your Servant-Maid, but 'twas I that met you there with Chaste Embraces.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: By her own Confession she hath been playing the Whore; yet I must bear the blame:— Had ever poor Cuckold such Fortune before! (Aside.
Indeed Wife, I was not there; I suppose you had good Evidence to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Is it not enough, thou Villain! that thou art false to my Bed, but thou wouldst make me belye my own Senses? Do'st thou think to brave it thus? I'll make thee repent, thou Ungrateful!—

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Now must I crave pardon for her Offences. (Aside.

I saw a great and mighty Monster come forth from thence just now, with four Legs, and one Cloven-foot, and two Horns as long as an Elephants Snout, Eyes like Barbers Basons, grin'd and spit Fire as he past along: I fear'd he wou'd have burnt me; the Brimstone is not yet out of my Nose— Indeed Wife, under Correction, and the Circumstances consider'd, the Devil hath been a little to familiar with you.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Thou wouldst perswade me 'twas the Devil, but I am well satisfy'd to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Then I hope you are convinc'd of the Mistake.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: This Impudence (my Friend) must not pass unpunish'd: Were it as thou say'st, 'twas thine own seeking; a just Reward, and no fault of mine.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: No, you Women are never in fault.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: To meet my Husband there, was my intent;

div.head: ACT V. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: WAs it your Project (Mr. Trusty) to cheat me of my Children?— I wonder what they have done with the Squire Smash, for I can hear nothing of him?— They will not, I suppose, keep him any longer in durance upon this Fob-Action, since Sir Patrick Greedy knows nothing of the matter.— Keep your great Tynn-work to your self, Mr. Manley; I'll not be bubled thus out of my Daughter; I hope to bestow her better, tho' I confess I was almost betray'd.

sp.speaker: Maid within.
sp.p: Fire! Murther! Thieves!

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: My Bags! my Gold! my Money! [Runs about the Stage in a Fright.

div.p: What's the matter? Is the House a-fire?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Worse, Sir, worse!

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Am I robb'd of my Gold?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Worse, Sir, worse!

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: What can be worse? Tell me in short.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! my Mistress!—

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Run away with Manley!—

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Worse, Sir, worse!

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: She is not murther'd, is she?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Worse, Sir, worse!

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Do not dally with me; I'll have it out, or tear it from thee.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: You need not be so inquisitive after bad News, that will make every Joint of you tremble.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: I'm become thy Sport and Pastime. [Goes towards her.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I have done, Sir.— [Exitura.

div.stage: [Gripe runs and takes her by the Throat.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! I will.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Tell me immediately, without the least Evasion, or I will throttle thee this very minute.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Last night when I came from my Mistress's Chamber, I drew the Courtains, and lock'd the Door; this morning I tremble to declare what I espy'd.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Again! (Loud.) [She starts.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Nothing— but Mr. Manley in Bed with her.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Lovingly clasp'd in each others Arms asleep.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: There may they sleep their last— Is this the fruit of all my Pain and Care, to have nurtur'd a confounded Harlot! [In passion.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Good Sir, no such hard words: I dare say Mr. Manley is a lovely Bed fellow— I heartily wish'd my self in my Mistress's place.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Wou'd any other had been there but she.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I wa7'd 'em, Sir, and then made bold to tell her so: She clapp'd him on the Cheek, and kiss'd him; quoth she, I will not part with my dear Manley for all the World.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: An excellent Relation of a lewd, lascivious Whore.— I curse the time that ever I begot her.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I am confident I lock'd the Door close; O' my Conscience he is 〈◊〉 Witch, or he could never have got in.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Such young Fellows always carry Pick-locks about 'em.— Go, get you in, I have no more to say to thee. [Exit Maid. Oh for a Curse to plunge 'em deep enough!— May she still love him to excess! want Bread and Sustenance to feed their crying Younglings! ●…ay they abound in nothing but Misery!— This is the greatest Cross that e'er befel me.— Now to prevent my Son's ruin, I'll match him forthwith to the rich Widow Bryant, lest he grows mad again or Manley's Sister; I have given him my Writings, and hope my Friend Cunningame hath drawn the Settlement.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: If I miss of my Eugenia, I am for ever lost; nor must Manley's Marriage be yet known. (Aside.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Good morrow, Peregrine; where hast thou been this Morning?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Where I have heard more of Mr. Trusty's Tricks, Sir.— He and his Confederates, with Sharper's treacherous Assistance, have rook'd the Squire Swash of all his Money, and turn'd him to the Country without Clothes: I was searching to befriend him in his Adversity.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Step softly into thy Sister's Chamber, and steal away Manley's Clothes; he is this time debauching her,

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: How, Sir!— They certainly have both more Vertue in 'em.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: They have been all this night in bed together; what precious Acts of Vertue have been done, you may easily judge.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I'll in immediately and cut his Throat. [Offers to draw, and run out, Gripe holds him.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Nay, good Son be patient; that's the way to be without thee too.— One a Whore, and the other be hang'd, is a great Scandal to a Family.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Pray Sir, let me go: Shall any Man dare to abuse our Family, and Peregrine not revenge it? Such a Disgrace I cannot, will not bear.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: But, Son, as I told you before, 'tis a greater Disgrace to be hang'd for killing of a Rogue: When you come upon the Gallows, to be able to cry, Good People, here I am come to take my last Swing in the World, for cutting the Throat of one who dishonour'd our Family. So being ty'd up, the Valorous Mr. Peregrine Gripe and his fine Speech end together.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: He hath given her Philters sure, or she would not so basely have yielded to him.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Give him his due, as far as I can understand she is very well pleas'd with him.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Ten thousand Curses on the Prostitute! Will he not Marry her?— I'll make him.—

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Rather let him pine in hungry Repentance, till Starving bring 'em to their Senses. Go instantly fetch the Writings hither; I'll forthwith Seal 'em; then thou may'st make me happy, at least in one Child.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: And tamely thus without Revenge?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: The best Revenge can be taken; therefore on my Blessing I enjoin thee to go without the least Delay, Regret, or Hesitation.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: My Duty binds me; I obey. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: I begin to have some hopes of this Boy; he is dutiful and respectful to me.— But I must secure him for fear of a Relapse.— Oh my Clarinda! my Clarinda!

div.p: Manley! thou Villain, what hast thou done?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Keep the Villain to thy self, Old Midas; I was more kindly entertain'd within by thy Daughter; she gave a Night's Pleasure and Content; and Luck hath fail'd, if there be not a Grandchild in store.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Very joyful News indeed!— Now you come, I suppose, thinking to hector me into a Compliance.— Give a good Fortune, say you, and I'll Marry her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
You are mistaken, Sir; I expect none of your Money; you had better keep it to maintain her Offspring; while you are upon your Good-behaviour,
I may be now and then somewhat towards it: So a good morning to you. [Exiturus.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: As you have taken possession of the Tenement, take it with all its Incumbrances.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I have had a quiet and peaccable Possession as long as I desired: I found the Soil barren and unfruitful; I have manur'd and till'd it up, and at Harvest you may reasonably expect a good Crop: What could any Man do more. (Exiturus.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: You had as good take your Bedfellow with you; I'll maintain neither her nor her Bastard.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Then the Parish must, if she can't work: I'll care for the Child, if she lays it to me, and leave her to the Law.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Why sure he will not be such an inhumane Monster! A Gentleman, and leave his Lady of Pleasure to the Law! my Daughter too! 'Tis monstrous! [Aside.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: As you and she behave your selves: I tell you what Provision I'll make for her; I took her for présent Pleasure and Variety; sometimes, because 'tis a pretty, loving, good-natur'd Thing, and for my Recreation, I may give her the Honour of a Visit; but never think I'll marry her.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: If thou dost, thou shalt not have one Groat with her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Keep it, Miser, keep it: Do'st think I'll ever be confin'd within the Bonds of Matrimony, as long as I can have a young, beautiful, good-humour'd and ingenious Mistress at my Command? Ha, ha, ha! what Years Child d'ye take me for of, Dad? or where was I bred? Once more good-morrow; remember me to your Son. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: I wish he may not see thee too soon.— How the Rogue boasts of his Plunder!— What shall I say to Squire Swash! Shall I marry him to Manley's Leavings? No; he smoaks the matter, and comes no nearer; and Manley scorns what he hath himself debauch'd.— She and her Brat will be left on my hands.

div.p: Here she comes, now for a compleat Excuse; That she was Ravish'd, and with the Fear fell into a Swooning, which held her all night, that she could not cry out. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Did you not see Mr. Manley pass this way just now, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: This is what I little expected.— No Tear!— No Blush!— No Concern!— Oh Tempora! Oh Mores!—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, in time to work him to your Mind; he is much more loving than ever.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Sweet work! Beyond the strength of Imagination! You that yesterday were so brim full of Vertue! Where is it now? A meer sham. As the most zealous pretender to honesty, only waits an opportunity cunningly to Act the greatest Villany, so the most seeming Coy Lady, privately proves the most rampant Harlot.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What you talk is Mystery to me. Pray, Sir, what is it troubles you?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: 'Tis the Devil of a Daughter. Infamous Clarinda! What hast thou done?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Nothing but what I ought in obedience to your positive commands,— did you not charge me on your Blessing, to use all arts and means, that might reclaim him.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Thou willingly mistakest me, did I Commission thee to be a Whore? (Cla. weeps.

div.p: Here comes the cursed Author of my ruine.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Still at thine old Play! Lecturing thy Daughter? As how? What new offence? I prithee tell me.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: The natural effect of thy cursed contrivance: thy Nephew Manley hath dishonoured my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Have the young People been reciprocally kind? your Family is like to encrease without paying any Portion or Tax for Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Though you think you have hit the Mark, I must tell you, you have mist your Aim, the breach is too wide ever to be reconciled, you have indeed robbed me of my Child— Here, take her, lead her to her Gallant, let 'em have cost and care mixt with their Pleasure; the sowr sauce, may quicken the Appetite; or what think you of sending her to London? she may be very serviceable to the young Mathematicians, or where you will, she is no longer mine, while I lay up for one hath better deserved.

div.stage: Enter Perigrine, Cuningame and Shuffle with Writing, Pen and Ink.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I have pursued your positive Commands with some reluctancy, Pray, Sir, have yet some pitty on my Sister; forget and forgive; she might be trapan'd.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: When People have been Whoring after their own Inventions, for a pretence they'll say they were trapann'd, give me the Deeds, who drew 'em?

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: I drew 'em, Mr. Cuningame perused them.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I carefully weighed each Grant and Covenant exactly to your Model, as sure as proportion it self, but for your better satisfaction, you had best read it over.

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: If he make use of the Complement we are all undone. (Aside.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Being offered, nothing is suspected.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Perigrine looks strangely upon Manley, his Fingers itch to be at him. (Aside) Fetch me a Candle and Wax.

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: There's a Candle in the next Room. I don't use to go without my Tools. (Exit and Enters again with a Candle.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Here— (Delivers to Peregrine) I deliver this as mine Act and Deed to your use— I make it my request, that Mr. Trusty and Mr. Manley be two of the Witnesses. (Both Sign it.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: It lies very hard upon your Daughter Mr. Gripe.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: If something else had not been, this might have been prevented. (Aside to each other.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: We have done Sir.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: No further occasion for me Sir?

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: Nor me?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: For neither.

sp.speaker: Shuff.
sp.p: Let's be gone before it be discovered, the worst he can say of us we have been true to our Clients. (Aside.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: And good reason, for we are well paid. (Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Mr. Manley will you have a Portion to Marry my Daughter, or a Settlement? Draw it your self you are a great Scholar, and a Star-Gazer; see if you can find it in the Milky way, give you joy of your great Bargain. Perigrine, Now when you please you may Espouse your Widdow.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Sir, This my intended Wife, joins with me craving your Blessing. (Takes Eug. by the hand, both kneel.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: What dost mean Man,— 'Tis settled in consideration of a Marriage intended with the Widdow Bryant.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: By the name of Eugenia, Daughter of Humphry Manley Esq Deceased.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Ha!— Cheated again! I have but two Children in the World, a Rogue and a Whore: A hopeful pair! (never stir) but where is friend Cuningame now, where is he?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: He and Shuffle, like Physitians to a Languishing Patient, are both slip'd away, before the Death-fit comes.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Friend Cuningame a Knave? Then I think all the World are so.

div.stage: Enter Parson, which Manley seeing, takes Clarinda by the hand, both kneel.
div.p: What more tricks still— (never stir!) you won't Marry her, will you Mr. Manley?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: That I did yesterday, this honest Parson joyn'd our hands, our Hearts long since united.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: (Never stir!) If it were in Lawful Matrimony 'tis so much the better— Are you really a Priest Sir?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: At present only a Journey-man of the Church, a Curate of the next Parish, I hope in time to obtain a Benefice, and then I shall be finisher of the Work.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: And grow as Fat and Lazy as the rest of thy Brethren. (Aside. Did you Marry this pair?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I join'd their Hands, and tyed 'em by the Tongue, and gave 'em a Spiritual Commission to act other things if they pleased.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: A bold venture Mr. Manley; what will become of her Portion now?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I'll make Provision for your Daughter out of my own Estate, as your Son must for his now Eugenia.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And since thou beginnest to be somewhat reconciled to these Matches, and to make Manley the more deserving thy Clarinda; I'll immediately settle my Estate one half to my Nephew in Possession, in Fee simple, and the remainder after my death.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You were always a Father to me.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: I vow I think thou wilt prove an honest fellow at last— Heavens bless you all, I am heartily reconciled to ye, I am heartily glad that my Children prove to be Cheats, convincing Arguments to me, that what ever betides after my death, they'll be able to shift in the World. (Aside— And to say Truth, the Father was the fittest to begin with, 'tis reckon'd no Sin, at least a very small one, to cheat Parents, and Conscience is not prick'd till fully feared.— Moreover Clarinda proves to be honest, I am now as mad for Joy, as I was some minutes since for Sorrow.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: And is not this better than Wedding her to that Weather-cock; one that would have allow'd her no other Company than her Servants? He is such a Slave to his Recreations, he hath hardly time to sleep; and all the Satisfaction she should have, wou'd be to lie by a belching, strong Beer or Brandy-Cask, who no sooner wakes, but exit, and you hear no more of him, till after midnight again.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: I understand you, Sir: I have not paid you my thanks for helping to cheat me; I am your obliged Friend and humble Servant, Sir.— Parson, I must have this other Pair match'd too, therefore beware we don't miss the Canonical Hour.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: The Canonical Hour shall be at your Service till midnight.

div.stage: Enter Busy leading Margaret; Freeman, Sharper, Froth and his Wife.
div.p: Here come some that have been with me for a Cast of my Office before.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: The Captain's married to this Lady.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: Yes, Gentlemen; and, Ladies, I am marry'd.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: I heartily wish you Joy; she is a great Fortune, and the fittest Wife for you that I know: She must needs understand her Exercise; she hath been bred under a good Officer any time these seven years.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: What's the meaning of this, Freeman?

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: Nothing but a Banter; he only envies your Fortune.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: I have had but a scurvy Night on't; every one that met me, shunn'd me for a Ghost; at last by great difficulty I got into a Hay-loft; poor and cold Lodging for a Person of my Quality.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: How now, Squire! stript as if you intended for a Race.— I wish you may make more speed about your next Mistress; this is marry'd before you come.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: I did suppose some such thing by the Arrest.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Every particular, both as to the Arrest and Marriage, were without my Consent or Knowledge.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Your Daughter marry'd without your Consent?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: And bedded too: Between 'em they have cheated me of all.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: A blessed deliverance! If she consent to cheat her Father, she will make no scruple to abuse her Husband; and Marriage at the best is but a bitter Sweet.

sp.speaker: Sharper.
sp.p: thou Villain, art thou there?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, be not angry; every Age and Country produces Precedents innumerable for what I have done; it hath been the practise of many ingenious Servants of all Qualities, to build their Fortunes on the Ruins of their Masters.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: I'll home and study the two great Businesses of Mankind, Interest and Dissimulation: I find 'tis to no purpose to perswade a Woman against her own Inclinations.— Madam, I wish you joy.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I heartily thank you, Noble Squire.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p:
In the midst of all my Misfortunes, one very pleasant Accident befel me: rambling last Evehing in the dark, I crept into a little Door, where I found a Woman waiting with a Stock of Love for another Man:
I quickly reap'd the Crop, rusht from her, satisfy'd with such a pleasant Plunder—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Do you know the Woman?

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: No indeed.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: I am glad of that however. (Aside.

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.p: Pray Mrs. Wife, with humble submission be it spoken, do you understand the meaning of this, Did Nicholas Froth Cuckold himself or no?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Peace; what was done, was thine own seeking, and can't now be prevented; therefore no more words of that matter.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: I will declare thy Infamy in the face of the whole Word.— O yes!—

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: I must speak him fair, or he will out with it in earnest. [Aside.
Sweet Nicholas, be silent.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Do you begin to alter your Tone? If I grant Peace, it shall be on very honourable Conditions.— Imprimis, will you Cuckold me no more?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: No, Nicholas, no.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Nor keep a Conventicle of Whoremasters Sundays Afternoon, about Business, to the Dishonour of my Person and Profession?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: No, Nicholas, no.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Wilt thou henceforth be dutiful and obedient to the just and lawful Commands of thy Supreme and Soveraign Lord thy Husband?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Yes, Nicholas, yes.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: As long as you faithfully keep your Promises, I will be silent; but no longer.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Who is that with the Captain?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: His Lady; they were Marry'd this morning.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: 'Tis our old Dairy-maid Peg; we have been very familiar seven years ago.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: Ha! this is very suspicious.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: Now all will out; Children and Fools speak Truth. (Aside.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Freeman hath kept her these two Years to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: Is this true, Mr. Freeman?

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: I cannot deny the matter of Fact; undermining and counterming belonging to the Art Military I thought fit to practise upon you, that you might instruct me if I acted amiss.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: This Discourse makes you melancholy, Captain.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: So it would any Man in my Condition— This comes of Pride and Covetousness, the singular Vertues of Mankind: Where are now my Welsh Manors and Bartons, Plantations, &c. Poor Captain Busy! thou wer't never beaten at this Weapon before.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: Give me Two hundred pound in hand to maintain the Child, and 40 l. per Annum to the Wench for Life, for separate maintenance, I'll take 'em off your hands.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: Two hundred pound Fine, and 40 l. Rent to be Cuckold for Life!— If Whoremasters be Christians, have a little more Conscience in your ways.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: I am very indifferent whether you accept the Offer or not; therefore expect no abatement; hitherto I have born the expence of my Pleasure, I intend now to share the Profit, and you shall pay for nibling.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: These be your floating Islands and Plantations: I might have consider'd foreign Wealth shrinks in Carriage.— My hand is in the Lion's mouth; I must agree with him.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Understanding of a Wedding, we come to present you with a Sett of Musick.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: With all my heart; we'll have a Song and a Dance, and then to Church and say our Prayers very devoutly.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: You have had time to consider, Captain, what's your Resolution.

sp.speaker: Busy.
sp.p: I do comply.— Come, 'tis a Bargain.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: While they go Church, we will go to Nich. Froth's, and confirm it.
sp.l: We are all Friends; and since the Bargain's made,
From this time forth I will forswear the Trade.

div.head: EPILOGUE. Spoken by Miss CHALKE, Seven Years Old.

lg.l: I Have a Secret, I wou'd fain disclose
To the Pretty, Witty Gentlemen call'd Beaus:
'Tis this;
If you will spare our Poet's Play to night,
(Altho' at present I can't do ye right)
You shall have my First Fruits when I'm a Woman;
As I hope to be sav'd I never yet knew no Man:
No, truly now, I'm so ignorant of Sin, or Schism,
I hardly yet can say my Catechism.
I'm mightily giv'n to play, and that's a Fault;
I'll mend a-pace tho'; I won't be always naught:
I live, you know, where I can't but be well Taught.
I've learn'd so much already behind the Scenes,
I know what a Billette Doux and Ogling means:
I know what Man keeps Somebody; nay, I know more,
I know she that will Kiss for Money, is a Whore.
Let the Men-Players leave off when they will,
Our Maiden Gentlewomen will scarce lie still.
Nay— you may laugh at a young Innocent Creature;
But I know more than you think tho', of the matter.
I know the World's a Stage, and do not wrong ye;
You're better Actors there, than we're among ye;
Because to act you's not so hard a Task,
As 'tis for you to act a Vizard Mask.
If we give Place to you, 'twill make no strife;
We only Copy, you Draw to the Life.
What is't I don't know, unless it be the THING,
For which the Beggar's equal to the King.
But if that want of Knowledge be a Transgression,
I'll know that too at Years of Discretion.
Mean time if you'll excuse the Errours of this Play,
When I'm Fourteen, it shall be more in your way.
I can't please now, as well as Eight Years hence.
But if you Men of Love are Men of Sence,
As an Old Nurse instructs a Smickering Maid,
When she sits stroaking little MARK of Lad,
My Penny'll show ye how a Shilling's made.
